He is in his 40th season with the Green Valley Cricket Club and, at the age of 59, he will be lining up to take the field this year and will be looking to score runs and take wickets.

The Laurie Hamptons of this world are the people who should receive our praise for their efforts early and often. Laurie is the sort of person who is best described as a quiet achiever. He has put in the hard yards at grassroots level to keep the cricket club going over many years. This club has provided an outlet for many young people in the Green Valley area. I congratulate Laurie on his contribution to the community of south-western Sydney and I look forward to hearing many reports of huge scores and large wicket hauls as the season progresses. Laurie Hampton truly is a man who has given a great deal to the youth of the area and he typifies the very notion of a community builder.

talk.start.para: âI bring to the Houseâs attention today something of great concern to the small and medium businesses in my electorate of Stirling and in Western Australia at largeâthat is, double dipping by the Gallop Labor government on stamp duty on motor vehicles. This double dipping is damaging to the motor trades industry in Stirling and to the motor trades industry in WA. Whilst getting record levels of GST, record levels of stamp duty and running a $1 billion surplus, the Gallop Labor government is whacking car dealers for stamp duty if a car is loaned out to a staff member for as little as a day.

speech.para: Further revenue raising through charging stamp duty on vehicles being used in a private loan capacity by the car yard is, quite frankly, daylight robbery. It is totally unfair on the hardworking members of the motor trade industry, who deserve a break from this unfair impost. Just to put into perspective, for the benefit of the House, what this double dipping means: when a vehicle is used on leave for a day by a member of staff it becomes dutiable, and that stamp duty must be paid by the dealer. If it is sold the following day, it is again dutiable. In that case, the stamp duty is paid by the customer. To simplify this situation even further: the Gallop government is charging excessively high levels of stamp duty on the vehicle in question, not once but twice.

This is quite clearly an unashamed and classic case of double dipping by the WA Labor government, although I am not really surprised by this shameful practice. With the government persevering with its damaging and counterproductive policy, many small businesses in Stirling have been burnt by this poor decision making and by the lack of public policy direction. When small businesses like motor traders suffer, the state suffers and the larger national economy suffers. However, we could alleviate this problem tomorrow by recognising and altering this policy of double dipping.

It is time for Premier Gallop to jump off the economic wave of success created by the Howard government through much-needed economic reform and responsible management and do something about unfair tax double dipping, to get off the backs of the small and medium businesses in Western Australia. This can be done tomorrow by recognising that the GST payments have made Western Australia far richer than it would have been under the old taxation arrangements. Geoff Gallop can scrap not only all of the taxes he agreed to under the intergovernmental agreement but also inefficient and damaging stamp duty surcharges. Furthermore, Premier Gallop must recognise that a state budget surplus of over $1 million should be spent not on workers attending pointless rallies but on scrapping and cutting the highest levels of stamp duty in the country. So I say to Premier Gallop and the Western Australian state Labor government: give motor traders in Stirling and Western Australia a break and do not put your hands in their pockets unfairly twice.

talk.start.para: âI want to say a few words this morning on behalf of my constituents who currently contribute to private health insurance. The government should really be using its powers to ensure that these people, who spend considerable sums of money on private health insurance, in fact receive value for the high costs of their coverage. In a local survey of constituents on a range of medical issues, I asked them questions to do with gap payments, and 74 per cent reported that their gap payments had increased, which is not surprising. When I asked whether they received value for money from their fund, almost 62 per cent said no. I am not surprised by that response either.

speech.para: Recent figures released by the Minister for Health and Ageing based on a survey of more than 4,000 private hospital insurance claimants showed that 44 per cent of patients were left facing extra bills on top of their coverage, the money that they outlayâan average of $720 per hospital stay. So, after paying somewhere in the order of $1,000 to $2,500 in premiums, according to this survey some patients were paying up to an extra $1,250 for their treatment. Is it any wonder that people feel they are not getting value for money from their coverage?

I find that in my electorate a lot of low-income earners and pensioners in particular go to the extent of sacrificing other things in life to pay for their private health coverage because they are anxious and worried that, in the event of an emergency, they might not be able to get the treatment they are after in the public hospital system. So a lot of them already take out private health insurance as a mechanism to cover against those contingencies.

The government, as you know, promised that their policies would lead to downward pressure on premiums. That is another broken promise. Private health insurance now is in fact 33 per cent more expensive than in 2001, and last year gap fees across the board rose by 19.2 per cent. This year, as you know, premiums rose by an average of eight per cent across the nation, but a number of my constituents were telling me that in the case of one fund, the NIB, premium increases ranged from 11.5 to 19.7 per centâin fact, an average of 17.3 per cent, double the so-called national average.

It is clear to me that Australians are paying more and getting less for their private health insurance. How is it that this industry, which is subsidised to the tune of almost $3 billion a year by Australian taxpayers, cannot come up with a product that covers all the costs when patients use a private hospital? The minister has the power to force insurers to get this problem fixed. He has the power to approve or veto increases in premiums, and he should insistâ(Time expired)

talker.name: Hunt, Gregory, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Mr HUNT

talk.start.para: âI want to bring to the attention of the House today two road safety matters within my electorate of Flinders, one within the town of Baxter and the other within the town of Mount Martha. In Baxter is one of Victoriaâs most dangerous black spotsâthat is, the intersection of the Baxter-Tooradin Road, Fultons Road and Hawkins Road. That intersection, at critical times of the day, has a large number of people travelling across the Mornington Peninsula, travelling on the north-south route, travelling to and from work and also travelling to local schools, which include Baxter Primary School and Mount Erin Secondary College and will soon also include Somerville Secondary College, not to mention the two primary schools in Somerville. All of those people are at risk because of the congestion, the misalignment and the situation in relation to that corner.

speech.para: I recently held a community meeting in Baxter, and the No. 1 issue for the town was the intersection of the Baxter-Tooradin Road, Hawkins Road and Fultons Road. There must be a significant upgrade of the intersection, a clarification of the rights of way, a widening of the road, and preferably either lights or a roundabout. There must be an upgrade of this dangerous and unsafe corner.

In addition, very close to that corner is a bridge across the railway line. At that point there is no extra pedestrian passageway, and many families take their small children, whether in prams or by foot, across that bridge. They do it knowing that there are large trucks rushing by. Provision must be made for pedestrian access across that part of the railway line. That is extremely important.

In addition to the urgent need for the state to upgrade the Baxter intersection, there is a problem with intersections in Mount Martha. At both ends of Bentons Road in Mount Marthaâat the Moorooduc Highway end and at the Nepean Highway endâare dangerous intersections which have long been in need of upgrades. In each case there should preferably be a roundabout, but if there are other means to address the issue then I am happy to accept them. Both intersections are important; both are high-volume traffic points. There have been fatal accidents on the Moorooduc Highway end. There have been many accidents on the Nepean Highway end. Both intersections must be upgraded. I urge the Victorian government to act immediately and not to wait for additional tragedy before upgrading in Mount Martha the Nepean Highway and the Moorooduc Highway intersections of Bentons road. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âPerhaps obviously, the sea is a major resource for creating economic development opportunities in Pacific island countries. The sea is the key to tourism development in the region. Some of the best scuba diving sites in the world are in the Pacific, and already this is a major part of their attraction to tourists. Scuba diving is a great recreation, but it has its dangersâmost importantly, the possibility of a diver needing treatment for the bends. Divers need access to hyperbaric medicine to avoid death or permanent disability in these situations, and medical evacuations are hugely expensive.

speech.para: A key health issue for many Pacific countries is the high incidence of diabetes. Diabetic patients often need hyperbaric medicine to avoid wounds that do not heal or that perhaps can lead to amputations.

Australiaâs aid program needs to be committed to advancing economic opportunities in the region as well as addressing health problems such as diabetes. A Melbourne company based in the south-eastern suburbs of Melbourne, Hyperbaric Health, already provides services in a significant number of Pacific countries. However, there is a need for such treatments, and an absence of suitable facilities, in Tonga, the Marshall Islands, Samoa, Kiribati and the Cook Islands. I request that AusAid have discussions with Australian companies such as Hyperbaric Health as quickly as possible with a view to assisting economic development in the region and providing services to tourists, including many Australian tourists, as well as to local divers who otherwise face potentially serious health consequences as a result of what is a fantastic recreational pursuitâdiving. Services should be provided to meet the health needs of local people whose incidence of diabetes is exceptionally high. Diabetes can be debilitating if it is not treated properly.

A relatively cheap set of technical possibilities is offered by Australian companies, which can provide the appropriate systems, management structures and financial structures to significantly advance tourism opportunitiesâparticularly sea based pursuits such as scuba divingâin a number of Pacific countries. Over recent years this particular company in Melbourneâand, I am sure, othersâhave advanced such opportunities, but they need cooperation from the Australian government, as the major aid donor in the Pacific, to further advance these opportunities to underpin economic development opportunities in the Pacific countries I have mentioned and provide them with an important health service in areas such as diabetes.

talk.start.para: âTransport is one of those issues for the people of Western Sydney that are always at the front of their mind. For many, that commute into the city for work is long, arduous and highly frustrating. Today I want to commend work being done by the federal government to help combat inferior transport corridors in Western Sydney. The Westlink M7 is an innovative project that promises to give relief to long-suffering commuters. The Australian government recognised the need to ease congestion and has invested $356 million into this critical infrastructure. At 40 kilometres long, this is the biggest urban road project in Australia. Given its size, the project has managed to pay close attention to the very real needs of residents near construction areas and to people who will make use of this road.

speech.para: I want to commend the provision of public transport corridors on the M7. Public transport is a key element to any sustainable transport strategy. I am extremely pleased that the people of Blacktown will have in the future more public transport options for easy travel around the greater Sydney area. In addition, I am pleased to note that consideration has been given to residents, with the construction of noise barriers to minimise disruption to those who live close to the corridor.

One of the benefits of construction of this size is the flow-on improvement to local infrastructure. For my community this means upgraded road infrastructure for Sunnyholt Road and Seven Hills Road. For too long residents have dealt with poorly maintained roads which are hazardous and prone to causing accidents.

The economic impact of the M7 cannot be overlooked either. More than 1,500 jobs have already been created through this process. This is an investment in the skills and ability of the people of Western Sydney. More than this, opening up Western Sydney to improve transportation can only act as a catalyst for the economic development of Western Sydney. My colleagues and I have long argued that the key to economic growth in our communities is improved access to the varied and diverse areas of Western Sydney. I am confident that the M7 will assist greatly in achieving this goal. Estimated forecasts predict that an extra 24,000 jobs will be created as a result of this improved accessibility within three short years of the motorway being opened. This is expected to generate more than $260 million for the Australian economy, demonstrating Western Sydneyâs importance on a national level. I commend everyone involved with the project and look forward to seeing the positive results yielded for the people of Greenway and for the people of Western Sydney.

talk.start.para: âI have here in front of me a seemingly innocuous press release put out by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission yesterday. If you study the implications of this press release, however seemingly innocuous it is, you will see it kills choice for millions of comprehensive car insurance policyholders in this country. The statement was put out by the ACCC yesterday under the authorship of Graeme Samuel, the chair of the ACCC. The headline says âACCC allows IAG choice of repairer policyâ. The statement says:

quote.para: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission will not overturn notified arrangements* for motor vehicle insurance policies offered by the Insurance Australia Group (IAG)**.

speech.para: What this statement and this decision mean in reality is that a person that takes out a comprehensive motor vehicle insurance policy, if they insure themselves with the Insurance Australia Group and if they want to have choice of their smash repairer after an accident, has to pay a premium of roughly at this point in time $69.

This is a very new concept. It is interesting that when this was raised by IAG in November 2004 I was approached by a gentleman called Gerry Raleigh, who owns a premium smash repair business. He told me what the actual consequence of this particular policy is. Basically, consumers think, when they take out car insurance, that they will not have an accidentâbecause people basically hope that they will not. So they believe that they do not have to pay the premium because it is not going to be a problemâthey are not going to have to worry about the accident. But in reality when they have an accident they will be forced to take, as a consequence of this decision, their car to the preferred smash repairer nominated by the IAG.

I have detailed in this House before the problems with this particular decision. What this is going to do in reality is take away choice. People will not pay this premium; they will not believe that they need to pay this premium. Therefore, if they have an accident, they will be forced to go to the preferred smash repairer nominated by the IAG. This is a policy that is about removing freedom of choice for consumers.

The ACCC is there to protect the rights of consumers and small business. This decision backs a big business practice which is almost extortionate in its practice. This is a terrible decision by the ACCC. It is a decision that affects small business owners like smash repairers and millions of consumers. This decision should be revisited, because it is an absolute disgrace.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on those unwelcome, unsolicited phone calls at night which we have all had to suffer that urge you to buy a product you do not really want. Lately I have noticed the rise in calls to my office from constituents, as well as letters, complaining about telephone marketing calls, particularly those from overseas from call centres in either India or Egypt. I have had a few of these calls myself, and I can only say that I sympathise with the frustration my constituents are expressing. One constituent described the experience as being besieged from overseas via satellite.

speech.para: I understand that in terms of local marketers, there exists a code of conduct to which most adhere. In fact, most members would be aware that there is an ability to register yourself on the âdo not callâ register of the Australian Direct Marketing Association. Australian companies generally respect such registrations. Unfortunately there are a few unscrupulous operators who ignore the code and persist in badgering customers.

Aside from pure sales pitches, there are scams about which the vulnerable need to be aware. I have found that the most vulnerable in our society are the elderly. It is a shame that unscrupulous telemarketers prey on their naivety and trust. At least with Australian companies we can do something about it through consumer protection legislation that we have in place.

It is the telephone calls from overseas that create the most angst. These people seem untouchable. They are persistent and intrusive. They ring at times when they know people will be home, usually around dinner time. And it is not just a single phone call. Often the calls occur in multiples in a short space of time. But the thing that seems to irritate people the most is the personâs accent and an inability to comprehend what is being said in reply. This just adds to the level of irritation. I suppose that in marketing terms you are hardly going to be in a frame of mind to purchase from them. In the end, it gets down to whether an individual can overcome their ingrained conditioning to be courteous, and just hang up on them.

I know there are difficulties in regulating this sort of intrusion. A couple of years ago we went through the problem of email scams, which are similar in context. It seems that everybody all over the Western world shares this problem, with the result that some governments have set up âdo not callâ registration schemes. But, as I have said, they are of no benefit if the call comes from overseas. It is something I would like the government to look into. Perhaps we can undertake a program of consumer awareness, but I suspect that will only open the government to accusations of wasting taxpayersâ money.

There are some devices on the market which consumers can connect to their phones; at the touch of a button, they can then tell the telemarketer to remove the number from their list, and hang up. The same can be achieved by the simple method of hanging up. After several attempts, the telemarketer will take you off the call list. It is just a matter of people having the courage to be able to do that. By the way, a whistle by the phone works wonders.

talk.start.para: âThis morning I have been visited by TAFE teachers who are very concerned about the Skilling Australiaâs Workforce Bill 2005, which is in the Senate this week. The legislation has already passed the House. At the time of that debate, I raised my concerns. The legislation has the potential to threaten up to 25 per cent of TAFE funding. Australia currently has a massive skill shortage. This skill shortage needs to be addressed by more TAFE places and better training for our young people. Unfortunately, I see this bill as having the potential to impact on this enormously.

speech.para: This legislation is also looking at including industrial relations issues in a bill that is about funding education. It wants teachers to sign individual contracts. Funding cuts could mean that up to 450,000 students miss out on TAFE places. The teachers are most concerned, of course. They believe that this bill will lead to cuts to courses and course hours, which I tend to agree with, which means that there will be fewer courses offered at fewer locations. That will have an enormous impact in my area at Belmont TAFE. I raised the concerns of the Belmont TAFE teachers in my original contribution on the bill.

The legislation will mean a loss of courses in regional Australia and increased costs for TAFE courses when students are already struggling to pay the costs of their TAFE courses. It will mean increased class sizes because of a lack of funding. We all know that the larger the class sizes, the harder it is for students to actually learn and ask questions and get the information that they need. There are also a number of equity issues, and that is an area that is close to my heart. There will be less funding for programs helping students with disabilities. TAFE has a wonderful system of giving support to students with specific disabilities. It will also lead to a loss of staff and a lack of funding for professional development and updating industry skills. Funding for new equipment and technical support will suffer and there will be increased costs to industry and the community. TAFE teachers across Australia are most concerned about this, and so am I. People throughout New South Wales can express their concern about this issue by visiting www.nswtf.org.au/savetafe. I encourage everybody to visit that web site, have their say and let the government know their feelings on this matter.

talker.name: Billson, Bruce, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary (Foreign Affairs) and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs)
talker.name: Mr BILLSON

talk.start.para: âI rise today to talk about something that is of particular interest and concern to my communityâand it is an interesting topic to raise the day after there has been snow in Canberra. You might well be aware of my long campaign to have the Dunkley community recognised as the âSouthern Solar Cityâ. The Howard government in its wisdom and its foresight has provided a considerable amount of fundingâ$75 millionâto support the development of Solar Cities trials throughout Australia. Many people when they heard about that initiative thought, âHereâs a great idea. Letâs take it to the bright days of Adelaide or to some of the warmer climates along the eastern coast.â I thought to myself, âReally, that is going to be a bit of a no-brainer in terms of an exercise,â because we know those climates are very well suited to photovoltaic technology. The efficacy and the business case for solar electricity in those communities are not really up for question. What is more interesting and what I think the government should be supporting is proposals to see whether the utility and the efficacy of photovoltaic cell technology stand up and can be supported in a more temperate environmentâa more Mediterranean environment like the wonderful Mornington Peninsula.

speech.para: I have been arguing for a âSouthern Solar Cityâ to be part of the federal governmentâs Solar Cities program. Adelaide and Sydney, I know, have shown particular interest and some consortia have come together in Western Australia, but I am pleased that three groupings have come together in Victoria to put forward the proposition of investing some of that money in the more temperate climate of Victoria. What is particularly encouraging and pleasing for me is that one of those consortia actually involves the municipalities and the community that I represent in the greater Frankston-Mornington Peninsula region. Naturally, the proposition, the business case, the competitiveness of the proposal from our region needs to be tested against other regions. I urge the stakeholders in that local consortia to put their very best foot forward.

But I am urging also that the government consider that what we are trying to gain out of the Solar Cities program is not only support and momentum for the use of photovoltaic technologies but a business case. We need to road-test the technologies in a range of climates so that the Australian community, the business community and local and state governments around Australia can see that this is a credible alternativeâa renewable energy source that, when deployed in a residential, industrial, municipal or civic environment, secures benefits whether you are in the bright sunlight of the middle of Western Australia or a temperate climate such as the Mornington Peninsula. Our communityâmy friend the member for Flinders is here with meâhas the appetite for this technology. Our cities and our shires are well advanced in the Cities for Climate Protection program. We should get behind this proposal. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)âIn accordance with sessional order 193, the time for membersâ statements has concluded.

debateinfo.title: NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY (EXCISE) LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 2005

cognateinfo.title: NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY (CUSTOMS) LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 23 June, on motion by Mr Entsch:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âThe opposition supports the National Residue Survey (Excise) Levy Amendment Bill 2005 and the National Residue Survey (Customs) Levy Amendment Bill 2005. The proposed amendments in the legislation insert a new operative levy of 0.075c per kilogram for fresh apples and pears produced in Australia and also increase the present maximum rate of 0.060c per kilogram for apples and pears produced in Australia to 0.10c per kilogram. The new maximum levy rate has been put in place to allow the apple and pear industries scope to increase the operative levy rate should further funds be needed for a residue-monitoring program. The amendments have the support of our important apple and pear industries in this country. As I have indicated, the opposition is happy to support the bills and facilitate their passage through the House.

speech.para: The monitoring of chemical residues in fruit and vegetables is an extremely important task that provides consumers in Australia and in our export markets with guarantees as to the safety of the products they are buying. In the context of this debate, I want to raise a matter which is of considerable concern to Australiaâs fruit and vegetable growers, especially to the growers who are in Canberra today as part of the Fair Dinkum Food Campaign. On 20 June this year, a former agriculture minister, Warren Truss, told the parliament:

quote.para: ... imported foods are required to meet exactly the same food safety standards as foods produced in Australia.

speech.para: That was reported in Hansard. It is not an accurate statement of the facts at all. Imported fruit and vegetables are tested for only 25 pesticide residues, while our local producers are required to meet quality assurance standards for up to 65 chemicals.

The requirements that government places on Australian producers with respect to chemicals are significantly more onerous and costly than the requirements that are placed on our international competitors. The government requires beans from Belgium, tinned tomatoes from Italy and sweet corn from Thailand to be tested for only 25 chemical residues, but it demands that Australian farmers competing in the same marketplace meet standards for 65 chemical residues. Australian producers do not mind meeting international competition on equal terms, but this is currently not the case. It is time that we looked closely at the requirements we place on imported product in respect of chemical residues, to ensure that they meet the same rigorous standards that we demand of Australian growers.

It is the Australian consumer who has an eye not only for price and quality but also to their own health status and the health status of their families. I have been suggesting to the agricultural sector in this country that it needs to be more proactive in the health debates here, because preventative measures are at the heart of that health debate, and one of the keys to disease prevention is nutritious food.

It is very important that consumers are able to clearly identify the foods that they want to consume. This is an emerging debate and, of course, the Fair Dinkum Food campaign that reaches Canberra today is an expression among not only producers but consumers of those sentiments and of the concerns for accurate labelling so that Australian consumers can clearly identify that the foods they consume are safe.

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)âThe member for Corio would know that the chair is fairly clear on his rulings in speaking to the bill. I know the member for Corio would like to get some of this in the Hansard, but there are other forms of the House that he can use. This is a very simple billâit is about the levy. I have been tolerant, but I cannot let him wander too far off the bill.

âI understand that; I will conclude my remarks. I merely wanted to make the point that the level of chemical residues in food is a very important consideration not only for producers but also for consumers of food in this country. It is very important that governments at all levels ensure that, through the regulations that they put in place, the Australian consumer is able to clearly identify the foods that they want to consume and that those foods are clean. The opposition will be supporting the passage of the bills through the House.

talker.name: Hunt, Gregory, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Mr HUNT

talk.start.para: âIn summing up the governmentâs perspective on the National Residue Survey (Customs) Levy Amendment Bill 2005 and the National Residue Survey (Excise) Levy Amendment Bill 2005 I wish to make three brief points. The first is to note that, as was acknowledged by our friend in the opposition, the member for Corio, this legislation is about enhancing, improving and supporting the clean and green image of the Australian fruit and vegetable sector. It is fundamentally about ensuring that raw food products bound for export and domestic consumption are free from major chemical contamination. It is an obligation to consumers, it is an obligation to the receivers in other countries and it is the best single way of protecting and preserving not just the industry as a whole but individual players by ensuring that we have high standardsâthe highest in the world. We have to ensure that we protect, preserve and promote the clean and green brand which embodies Australiaâs fruit and vegetable industry and in particular, in this case, the apple and pear sector.

speech.para: That leads me to the second point. I, and on behalf of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Senator Colbeck, want to pay tribute to members of the apple and pear sector. I have within my own electorate of Flinders on the Mornington Peninsula a vibrant sector. They do it tough from time to time, but they are highly efficient farmers, they are well organised and they are very effective in the way in which they participate in an international economy. I wish to pay tribute to the apple and pear sector.

The third thing I wish to do is to acknowledge the work of not only the parliamentary secretary, Senator Richard Colbeck, but also departmental officials in the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and the National Residue Survey organisation. All of these activities and the actors play a fine role in working with and supporting the fruit and vegetable growers, in particular the apple and pear growers.

This legislation, as has been noted, seeks to raise the maximum level for the levy to approximately $1 per tonne, or 0.1c per kilogram, and it seeks to raise the operative levy rateâthe current implemented levy rate for fresh apples and pears exported from Australiaâfrom the present rate of 0.06c per kilogram, or 60c per tonne, to 0.075c per kilogram, or 75c per tonne, to assist in the process of testing and monitoring. It has been done in cooperation with industry. For those reasons I am delighted to commend both bills to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

debateinfo.title: NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY (CUSTOMS) LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 23 June, on motion by Mr Entsch:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That the Main Committee do now adjourn.

subdebateinfo.title: Geelong and District Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia

talk.start.para: âToday I would like to congratulate the Geelong and District Vietnam Veterans Association on their 30th anniversary. From humble beginnings as the Geelong Vietnam Association back in 1975, the association has grown over those three decades to where it has become an important focal point for the delivery of services not only to Geelongâs Vietnam veterans but to the wider veterans community in the region.

speech.para: As the association celebrates its three decades of active service for war veterans, it can well and truly take pride in the fact that it has discharged the sombre responsibility enunciated in its motto: âHonour the dead but fight like hell for the livingâ. With this anniversary, the Geelong and District Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia cements itself as a critical player in the welfare of Geelongâs veterans community generally.

The story has humble beginnings, from a meeting of young men in 1974 seeking to keep alive the camaraderie they had experienced in Vietnam. They formed the Geelong Vietnam Association in 1975 and marched under the banner in the Anzac Day march in that year. In 1979, following concerns about the health effects on Vietnam veterans of exposure to toxic chemicals in that war, a Vietnam Veterans Action Association was formed in Melbourne, and a sub-branch was formed in Geelong under the presidency of Dick Brady, with Alan Bone as secretary. Alan was later to become president of the Geelong RSL. In 1990, with Graham Brown as president and Alan Hughes as secretary, a new association, the Geelong and District Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia, was formed from an amalgamation of the two groups, and the great tradition of service to Vietnam veterans and others intensified and expanded over the next 15 years.

I became acquainted with the Geelong Vietnam veterans soon after my election as the member for Corio in 1993 when I was asked to attend the associationâs get together in the Drill Hall in Myers Street following the Anzac Day march. Since then, I have enjoyed a close association with Geelong Vietnam veterans and have admired the way they have confronted and overcome many difficulties and obstacles in their quest to care for their own and to care for others. It has been an interesting journey for Vietnam veterans, to the point where they occupy a special place in Geelongâs veteransâ community and an esteemed and respected place in the wider Geelong community.

Currently, the association operates the Geelong Veterans Welfare Centre out of St John of God Hospital and Geelong Private Hospital and conducts outposts at Colac RSL, Torquay RSL and Port Arlington RSL with the assistance in all of these centres of over 40 volunteers trained by the Department of Veteransâ Affairs. The associationâs services now embrace veterans from all other conflicts, and currently it has 4,500 operative files. A considerable majority of the 1,000 veterans issues the association handles a month relate to World War II veterans, and it is often when veterans from all conflicts call in for a chat that they come to apply for and receive their full DVA entitlements. The association is extremely proud of the Geelong Vietnam memorial and avenue of honour established at Osborne Park in 1995. It will be an important focal point of the celebrations this weekend.

To single out any past official or members of the association would do an injustice to those not so identified. So on behalf of the wider Geelong community I extend my thanks on the floor of this House to all members and officials over three decades who have made such a magnificent and dedicated contribution to the welfare of all veterans in the Geelong community. You have lived out your motto with dedication and integrity, and you have kept faith with your comrades, both living and dead, in the true Anzac spirit.

talk.start.para: âAnna Kunz is a 16-year-old student who attends the Illawarra Grammar School and lives in Gerringong in the electorate of Gilmore. During the last sitting she did a weekâs work experience here with me in Parliament House. I asked her to write a speech on her experience. She has, and I would like to read it onto the record. She wrote:

quote.para: For the last few years, whenever someone has enquired as to my aspirations after I leave school, Iâve replied with various levels of conviction, that one day Iâm going to be the Prime Minister.

Some people laugh, others talk about what a hard job it would be, but the most common reaction is that the person will commence a considerable spiel about what horrible, underhanded, liars politicians are, and why does a nice girl like me want to join such a corrupt system.

Considering such regular discouragement and the negative view so often taken by the media of our nationâs decision makers I jumped at the chance to spend a week here at Parliament House and find out the truth.
What are our nationâs leaders really like?
Last sitting I had a back stage pass to Australian politics.

Iâve walked past people in the corridors that I saw on TV the night before and had the amazing opportunity to speak to so many MPs and Senators from all parties about their beliefs and experiences as Australian politicians.
But surprisingly I havenât met any of the horrid liars that I heard so much about.
I entered Parliament House with some defined views about exactly where I stood on a number of current issues, and exactly what I felt the government was doing wrong.
I thought it was wrong to invade Iraq, wrong to lock up refugees in detention centres and that the government didnât care much about the environment.
But then I began to talk to people.
I discovered thatâs itâs not easy to try and argue with a politician.
When I challenged their position on an issue, they politely presented their view of the issue to me.
â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦
What bothered me the most about this though, was that many of my views were based on âfactsâ and information that turned out to be false or without backup.

I try to expose myself to a variety of media outlets and used to consider myself a fairly well informed person, however when I spoke to the MPâs who had access to first hand information on issues, who had spoken to persons involved and had evidence to back them up, the vague impressions I had received from the media was insufficient to answer back.
The scariest thing about coming to Parliament House was not finding out about which scoundrels run the country, because they are not scoundrels.
The scariest thing was finding out how ill informed many Australians are on important issues, and the true extent of bias within the Australian Press.
Regardless of whether everything the politicians told me was true, many revealed viewpoints and facts that the media has chosen to distort and ignore.
When the story doesnât suit the media and when it wonât sell papers the media wonât print it.
I believe the Australian people have a right to easier access to the facts.
Australians shouldnât have to go on a wild goose chase to find out basic facts about our communities, our nation, our world.
Australians deserve better access to both sides of the story.

Before I came to Canberra I had a general notion that the main political parties were a bit like dictatorships, the important people made all the decisions, and the back benchers automatically backed them up with people power.
Once I started meeting people, both Ministers and Backbenchers, this perspective began to change.
I discovered the huge amounts of work that people from any party, who are passionate about their electorate and passionate about the people they represent, actually put in.
I met inspiring people who genuinely cared about Australians, and regardless of their position within whichever party they belonged to, were prepared to fight for what they believed in.
It was very encouraging to talk to so many female politicians, who while still a minority are a dynamic force within the Parliament.
After discussing the history of women in politics I was surprised at just what a short time ago it was that there were few women in Parliament.
Girls today are born thinking that they can do anything, we take freedom for granted, and donât realise how recently Australia has become this way.
It was wonderful to see the growing female voice representing the women of Australia and to know that finally politics is becoming a level playing field for all Australians.
I met many interesting and inspiring women, perhaps one of them willâ

speech.para: one dayâ

quote.para: be our Prime Minister?
The other thing I hadnât realised before I arrived was the enormous team effort behind each Parliamentarian, particularly the ministers.
Parliament House is full of dedicated staffers, many of whom work just as crazy hours as the politicians who employ them.
Sometimes, as a sixteen year old Australian not old enough to vote, it can seem like youth donât have a voice in Australian politics.
Politicians love to have their photo taken with youth and talk about youth issues.
Building youth centres and endless talking about how youth should have more of a political voice are topics that get much publicity.
However when it comes to the issues that matter, issues that my generation will have to deal with the repercussions of in the future, the people in charge often donât want to hear our voice.

People who have labelled our generation as the well informed generation, but when you start talking about the environment and foreign affairs we are conveniently labelled too ill informed to have any input into the discussion.
Finding a realistic and open voice for youth can be hard because when politicians do try and talk to youth they are sometimes disappointed with the lack of interest and enthusiasm.
Yes, many youth arenât interested, but yes, many are.
People often group youth into one group with one opinion, but like any other generation youth have varying opinions on most issues.
So after one week behind the scenes, watching politicians work, and work and work some more, Iâve come away encouraged about the state of Australian politics.

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)âOrder! Unfortunately the honourable memberâs time has expired.
âMiss Kunz continues:

quote.para: I may not agree with everything the government says, Iâve come to realise that politicians are people not lawmaking machines, they are people that mostly genuinely care about the people they represent and about Australia.
Iâd like to thank my local member Joanna Gash ...
Itâs encouraging to know that these people do have time for youth opinions.

talk.start.para: âI cannot allow that to happen again.

âI rise for the second time today to talk about an issue of great concern to the people in my electorate. It relates to the deferred payment plan offered by ABC Learning Centres. A single mother contacted my office this week about her concerns regarding the increase in fees for her child care and about the deferred payment plan. She said that the only child care that she can obtain does not meet her needs. This particular individual, who we will call Joanne, recently received a letter from ABC Learning Centres, whose centre her child attends. The letter informed her that on Monday, 4 July her child-care fees would be rising. Her out-of-pocket child-care fees rose by 29 per cent and the child-care rebate has been soaked up in one hit by the higher fees. In the same letter, ABC announced that it had developed something called an ABC deferred payment plan, which says that it will allow families to reduce their family weekly child-care expenses immediately. It says this:

quote.para: From 4 July, all ABC families can elect to defer 30 per cent of their weekly out-of-pocket expenses, up to a maximum of $4,000 per child, per financial year.

speech.para: The repayment of the deferred amount will not be due until the end of September the following year.

About two days after receiving the letter, Joanne received the deferred payment plan credit terms and conditions, dated 16 June 2005, from DPPA Pty Ltd. These were the terms and conditions of the ABC Learning Centres deferred payment plan. The terms and conditions in this document make it clear that the deferred payment plan is a credit contract, a debt facility to pay your child-care fees. There is even a recommendation that a person taking up this offer obtain independent legal and financial advice before doing so. The deferred payment plan makes no bones about it:

quote.para: This is a loan to fund 30 per cent of the weekly child-care fees, up to $4,000 per attending child, in any financial year.

speech.para: As with other loans, borrowers must pay an interest rate, but in order to lure people into their scheme the operators do not call it an interest rate; they refer to it asâand this is a very interesting termââa charge for liquidated damagesâ. Under the heading âFees and chargesâ in the terms and conditions, it says:

quote.para: If you do not pay an amount when due and payable, under this credit contractâ

speech.para: which is to September the following yearâ

quote.para: you will be in breach of this credit contract and we may charge you liquidated damagesâ

speech.para: not interest rates; liquidated damagesâ

quote.para: of eight per cent of the overdue amount or any part thereof that remains unpaid on that date.

speech.para: I think that is called an eight per cent interest rate. There are even more nefarious provisions in this agreement, such as charging the amount of liquidated damages without consent. It may lock parents into the contract for a period of three years, and there are provisions relating to the cost of enforcement action taken to recoup unclaimed money from parents. Without pushing this point too far, it looks as though ABC Learning Centres in my region are becoming loan sharks by offering this particular facility to parentsâand there are a lot of parents in this area.

When schemes such as these are offered to parents, it is a clear signal that the child-care system has failed. It is proof that child care is so unaffordable that parents need lines of credit and loans to keep up. The promoters of this scheme even boast that it allows families to reduce their weekly child-care expenses immediatelyâbut, as I have outlined, that is not the case. The unequivocal impetus for this schemeâa scheme wanting parents to take on debt in order to meet their child-care costsâis the governmentâs broken promise on and mismanagement of the 30 per cent child-care rebate.

We know that the government made a promise during the 2004 election that all Australian parents could claim 30 per cent of their child-care expenses on or after 1 July 2005. After the election, the government broke that promise and announced it was pushing back the rebate by 12 months. Now the government has admitted that parents will not get 30 per cent of their out-of-pocket child-care rebate until the end of the financial year subsequent to the year in which the child-care fees were paid. So in some cases parents will have to wait two years to get this rebate paid. If parents like Joanne are struggling financially to pay their child-care fees and as a consequence get lured into this scheme, they are going to lose money, particularly if they cannot pay the entire amount back. I have run out of time. Therefore, Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to table the rest of my speech.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to speak on the issue of flow-through share schemes. This week Kalgoorlie has been hosting the Australian mining industryâs biggest event, Diggers and Dealers, with some 1,400 delegates. The hot topic of debate at the conference and at the dinner tables outside is the need for a flow-through share scheme in this country. The mining industry has again called on the Australian government to consider introducing these exploration funding incentives in order to show support for a vital sector of the economy. Flow-through share schemes allow investors to purchase a style of share which allows a 100 per cent tax write-off by the investor, whereas the company operating the costs can only write off costs to profit. On many occasions for greenfield explorers there are no profits.

speech.para: I have been a vocal supporter of flow-through share schemes and believe there is a need to sustain the mining industry in the long term. On two occasions I have arranged for a direct briefing of the Prime Minister by industry leaders. As a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry and Resources, I have arranged for leading industry figure David Reed to provide a detailed brief to all members. As a member of the committee I argued strongly and successfully during the inquiry into impediments to resource development for the Goldfields to be included in our visits for the collection of evidence and for a field trip to inspect exploration leases. A recommendation contained in the resulting report Exploring: Australiaâs Future was that taxation incentives be introduced to promote investment. This formal recommendation awaits positive government response. They have created a group of some 50 members and senators, âFriends of Mining and Resourcesâ, which meets each two weeks to hear from the mining industry about key issues. Flow-through share schemes have been raised on numerous occasions.

Australia was once a world leader in minerals exploration but we are now lagging behind Latin America, Canada and Africa. So many of our drilling rigs and professional teams are now operating offshoreâto the advancement of those countriesâ future in the mining industry. The biggest argument against the introduction of a flow-through share scheme right now is that the Australian mining industry is experiencing a boom. However, that boom will live only until the current resources known to the industry today are mined out. Those resources are not self-sustaining; they all have a finite life. Unless we are involved in greenfield exploration, and until such time as we make these all-important investments, there will be no major resources, and no development of those major resources, coming online. The only operators that are making great profits from existing operationsâby definitionâare those operating miners and operating mines and they, in the main, are certainly not involved in the exploration for greenfield. It is the smaller mining companies and explorers that undertake the lionâs share of greenfield exploration workâsomething that is vital for the future of this sector and, consequently, for the economic vitality of the nation as a whole.

The minerals industry represents 8.5 per cent of the Australian economy and produces one-third of Australiaâs exports. To protect and encourage our smaller mining companies and to support this industry in the long term we must adopt a flow-through share scheme policy in this country. I note that in the last 18 months the South Australian government, to their credit, have realised the net benefits of greenfield investment and have now made a 50 per cent contribution to the cost of a number of drilling projects. Pending a positive outcome from the federal government, I would strongly recommend that the West Australian government consider doing a similar thing.

Western Australian countryside is covered in regolith. It makes traditional prospecting and mineral exploration extremely difficult. High technology is required and therefore high cost is required to analyse the prospective greenfields in Western Australia. It takes a lot of money. It takes a lot of time. Unless we have a flow-through share scheme that will encourage investors to make investment into the greenfield exploration industry, we will see a time in the future when the existing resources have been mined out and we will have no bonus revenue coming from the mining industry. At that point in time I suspect that governments may cast about looking for who to blame for the shortfall in revenue.

talk.start.para: âSeveral factors come into alignment at this time. I would like to speak about three. The first is the coalition having control of the Senate. A gem from history makes a pertinent point. In 1936, Democrat Speaker, Sam Rayburn, said after Franklin D Rooseveltâs landslide win in 1936:

quote.para: When you get too big a majority youâre immediately in trouble.

speech.para: That point is demonstrably evident already, just three days into the spring sittings.

The second factor goes to what sort of country Australia is becoming. Is Australia becoming a country where the line between religion and state is inviolate? Is Australia becoming a country in which religion will trump science? Is Australia becoming a country in which leaders mobilise deep moral energies that divide us from each other and the world? Is Australia becoming a country in which women will not be allowed control of their own bodies? Is Australia becoming a country that intrudes into peopleâs sexual preferences? Is Australia becoming a country where religious energy is used in politics to promote division and intolerance? If it is happening, who decided it was on Godâs agenda? Is Australia becoming a country in which sectors of the community will be excluded from the political process?

The third factor is whether Australia is changing from a representative democracy to a manipulative one. As far as control of the Senate is concerned, Tuesday was day one. All the prophetic words of the 1936 Democrat Speaker in the United States ring true for the coalition government from 2005 to the probable election in 2007. It is a fair bet that Sam Rayburnâs prediction will come true, albeit in a different context and in a different country. We have the National Party, Family First, Barnaby Joyceâfancy putting forward arguments about representative democracy; naughty boy! We have Petro Georgiou, small âlâ liberals and Senator Eggleston. I suspect that, as the spring sitting proceeds, that list will become longer and longer.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I seek to ask a question.
âYou canâtânot in an adjournment debate.

âWhat sort of country is Australia becoming? Examples of the thinking on the governmentâs side became evident immediately after the last election. Of course, I refer to deliberately raising the issues of abortion and voluntary voting. It has always been a given that, if you want to divide the Australian community, you should introduce the topic of abortion. More responsible and more ethical people would introduce the topic of prevention of unwanted pregnancies. It is a gross irony to observe that the very people who strongly oppose abortion are often exactly the same people who oppose sex education and family planning to prevent unwanted pregnancies. The introduction of voluntary voting would dramatically reduce the participation of Australians in elections. A more responsible and unifying approach would be to introduce strategies to increase voter participation, not reduce it.

speech.para: That brings me to the third factor: the changing face of Australian democracy from a representative one to a manipulative one. More and more political comment in this country can be sourced back to fewer and fewer people. What passes as analysis is no more than opinion. What passes as current affairs often is no more than entertainmentâand gross at that. What passes as political comment is nothing more than spear throwing for selective power bases and individuals who are adept at manipulation of the truth and resistant to representative democracy.

There is a dilemma in political commentary: there is an ever decreasing number of powerful politicians and powerful people on all sides of politics who spend an inordinately large amount of time with fewer and fewer senior journalists ripe for political seduction, spinning information devoid of any analysis or national interest whatsoever. But it is not just the media. We all have to admit that there is a growing number of Australians who are now tired of political parties with their propensity to spin, their refusal to offend, their bland presentations and the relentless concentration on focus groups.

Political parties are becoming more and more controlled, constrained and conforming. As that fact becomes more and more evident, more and more people refuse to join. Branch stacking increases but participation reducesâit is quite an irony. Watching Australians deal with control of the Senate, citizensâ rights and an increasingly manipulative democracy, I think leading up to the next election may hopefully not be as straightforward as some in this place think it will be.

subdebateinfo.title: Phillip Island Australian Motorcycle Grand Prix

talker.name: Hunt, Gregory, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Mr HUNT

talk.start.para: âI wish to raise before the House today an act of carelessness and potentially of deception which has threatened the status, the future and the standing of the Phillip Island Grand Prix. The actor in question is the relevant Victorian minister for tourism, Mr Pandazopoulos. I wish to raise a series of activities. On 7 September last year Mr Pandazopoulos was recorded in the Sentinel Times as having said:

quote.para: ... the state government will not renew contracts for the Australian motorcycle and formula one grand prixes unless Canberra offsets the events huge financial losses.

speech.para: This was the beginning of a campaign against the local grand prix by the relevant state minister in the lead-up to the federal election to try and use and blackmail the federal government into providing additional funds. Let me start by saying that there are 19 major motorsport events in Australia. The federal government funds none of them, because the states compete aggressively to win the right to each of those. Of those 19 not one is funded by the Commonwealth. I note, just in case the issue is raised in response, that the Commonwealth has once given assistance to the Mount Panorama circuit at Bathurst for capital upgrades. But the operating costs are met for none of these 19 because each state and territory believes that there are extraordinary benefitsâas we know from when Victoria won the Grand Prix from Adelaide.

This matter was so important to the Victorian minister that by 1 December 2004, when he spoke in the Victorian parliament and said that he had sought funding from the federal government, he did not disclose the fact that there had been not one letter! By 1 December, three months after his initial statement, there had been not one letter. By 21 April there had still been no letter. He told the Victorian parliament, however, that he had written. Yet nothing had been received either by the minister for tourism or by the minister for sport at federal level. But he told the Victorian parliament that he had written.

After nine months, on 28 May, I received a letter from his chief of staff, and I am happy to table that letter. It said that the minister, Mr Pandazopoulos, who is also the Minister for Tourism, had written to the Commonwealth ministers for sport and for tourism. However, no letter had been received. On 21 July Mr Pandazopoulos again informed the parliament that he had written. Not only did he do that but he produced undated letters. Very interesting. This had been a live issue for 10Â½ monthsâhe had been under question about when the letters had been sent for 10Â½ monthsâyet he still maintained that, despite the fact that nobody at federal level had received the letters, that letters had been sent by him.

We produced in the Victorian parliament letters from both Commonwealth ministers saying that nothing had been received. So this minister had been under pressure and had either not done as he had said or, despite this clear public pressure, had failed to inquire as to why nobody had received them. Either you have an outright deception or monumental, continued carelessness. That is unacceptable, because it puts pressure on the people of Phillip Island.

Strangely, having accused not just me but also members of the Victorian opposition of an aggressive campaign against him on three occasions in parliament, on 9 August 2005 he confessed that the letters were never sent. He claims that he signed them, but he confessed to the parliament that a minor functionary in the department had never sent the letters. Yet for 9Â½, 10 and 11 months he had been under pressure as to the reality of these letters.

This was a clear misleading of the House. At the very least it was an act of monumental incompetence or, probably, deception of the highest orderâan elaborate distortion, an elaborate deception. This minister has not only failed the people of Phillip Island; he has repeatedly misled the Victorian parliament in order to cover up an initial deception. It is unacceptable conduct. It has been shown to be false, not just once but repeatedly. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âFollowing on from my colleague the member for Port Adelaide, I am starting to wonder where this country of ours is heading. There are not only terrorist alerts raising paranoia against individuals who look different and dress differently from we Anglo-Saxons; now we have the situation where attorneys-general want to further curb our basic human rights.

speech.para: I mention a recent hearing into overseas adoptions held by the Standing Committee on Health and Human Services. I notice that the chair and the secretary of that wonderful committee are here. Our committee heard evidence stating that photos of adopted children in a newsletter were prohibited by a Queensland government act. That absolutely amazed me. âHow bloody ridiculousâ, I thought. Here was a group of familiesâfamilies who wished to highlight the success of their adoptions and encourage and support other families through this difficult processâbeing made to feel like criminals. That was locked away in my mind.

Then, blow me down, yesterday in the Telegraph there was a report headed âInternet ban on children photosâ. At first glance, this seems okayâcommonsense. But what happens when you read a bit further? The report states:

quote.para: Posting photos of children on websites could become a crimeâeven if they appear to be wholesome family snaps.

speech.para: Just because we have a bunch of twisted perverts using the net for their own twisted sexual gratification, why do the rest of us have to suffer? With the advent of computer technology, many families who possess scanning facilities and their own digital cameras delight in emailing photos to other family members when special occasions occur.

My eldest daughter has lived in England. She and I possessed a web site. She delighted in sending me via email photos of family happenings in the UK that I was unaware of and that I wished to be made aware of. It gave me some satisfaction to see what my daughter and my extended family were doing in the UK.

Under the proposal by the A-Gs, sports teams, schools, community youth groups such as Scouts, the Red Cross, St John Ambulance and surf lifesaving clubsâgroups who regularly post achievements by members on their web sites to congratulate them and inform othersâare now potentially going to commit a crime. Attorneys-general, led by the federal Attorney-General, Philip Ruddock, have stated in a report that if such groups placed photos on web sites and they were then linked to pornographic web sites it would become a crime. Who is the onus on?

This all stems from three incidents. One concerned a man who was caught with 7,000 images of children, mainly in their swimsuits, taken in public places in Cairns. This person maintained that the images were innocent depictions of happy children despite them being posted on the internet. The second incident concerned a gay web site containing pictures of Melbourne schoolboys rowing and playing football. The pictures were taken without their consent. The third concerned pictures of a 16-year-old surf lifesaver posted on a gay web site.

Why are we not tackling these web sites and the people who are putting the photos up on them, rather than putting forward another set of laws that are going to punish innocent people who delight in extended family, relatives and others, and perhaps also people in community groupsâScouts, Red Cross, St John Ambulance and local schoolsâand who are doing the right thing? As do other members, I put out newsletters four times a year and I delight in extolling the wonderful virtues and achievements at school or in scouting groups and the like of young children in my electorate. Am I going to be committing a crime by putting them on my webpage, which people can access rather than reading my newsletters?

The Attorney-Generalâs Department has said that there is a consultation period until October. I urge the public to really look at this. We are taking a detrimental step. Let us get after the perverts who are setting up the web sites and taking these photos, rather than punishing families, community groups and the like, including politicians, who use such things sensibly and wisely. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âLast week I had the pleasure of launching an important Green Corps program in Warrien Reserve in Croydon North in the Casey electorate. The project is an initiative funded by the federal government. I want to take the opportunity this morning to place on the record my congratulations to the hardworking committee of reserve management there, and particularly to the young people who, in the next six months, are going to be performing that work in Croydon North. The Maroondah City Council is also involved. The combined hard work of the local Warrien Reserve Committee of Management, council officers and the people completing the Green Corps project will provide a major environmental boost to Warrien Reserve, which has a wonderful history of environment and environmental works in Croydon.

speech.para: Last year in this House I spoke about the Warrien Reserve Committee of Managementâs concern about the destruction of some habitat which occurred with illegal clear-felling by a developer in Bonnie View Road. The residents were naturally outraged by what happened. They have now put that behind them and they have continued to work to improve the reserve for the benefit of everybody in Croydon North and, indeed, throughout the electorate of Casey. It is one of those wonderfulâ
A division having been called in the House of Representativesâ

interrupt.para: Sitting suspended from 10.47 am to 10.59 am

talk.start.para: âBefore the suspension, I was talking about the Warrien Reserve. In 2001 a project to create a frog habitat in the reserve received a Keep Australia Beautiful award under the category of City Pride in land care. In 2002 it was nominated for a federal Banksia award. This newest preservation project, the Green Corps project at Warrien Reserve, will take six months to complete and has a number of core objectives. Its primary aim is to restore bushland habitat for the protection of two main species of endangered frogsâthe Victorian smooth froglet and the southern toadlet. An integral part of the project is the preservation of the native bushland in the reserve and the adjacent Everard Wildflower Sanctuary. The works will also create an alternative pond and frog-breeding site, reduce environmental weeds, provide general maintenance, plant suitable habitat, and develop an interpretive trail and an information board for members of the public. There will also be comprehensive surveying and monitoring of the frog population.

speech.para: This Green Corps project is another important project in the Casey electorate. It is providing practical environmental assistance to communities and is also providing practical and thorough training for young people in and around the Casey electorate in the importance of the environment and in the importance of working. This federally funded program, which began in 1996, is providing wonderful opportunities for young people in Casey and right across Australia. It allows 17- to 20-year-olds to develop important work force skills and experience in the area of practical environmentalism. As I said, the program is delivered nationally by the government through Job Futures and Greening Australia.

In the brief time I have left, I would like to acknowledge all of the participants who will work very hard at Warrien Reserve over the next six months. I will mention their names: Simon, Toni, Bradley, Ben, Pat, Bonnie, Jemima, Jonathon, Marcia and Nicki.

talk.start.para: Mr Billson interjectingâ

âI had the opportunity and the privilege to meet with each of them. While they are very well versed in the environment, they have not, I regret to say, heard of the member for Dunkley at this point, but I will make sure I point that out the next time I meet them.
(Mr McMullan)âThat is very close to a reflection; I will have to consider that one!

âThey are a keen group of people who are going to do a wonderful job, and I want to place on record my thanks to them and to the Warrien Reserve group of Keith Roper, Marie Ward and David Pockett, who will work alongside them and teach them a great deal about the importance of Warrien Reserve and the local environment generally.
âThe United Nations Youth Association states:

quote.para: Young people are not just the leaders of tomorrowâs worldâthey are a dynamic and diverse demographic that have much to offer today. Their views need to be heard and their skills and abilities not generalised.

speech.para: I, for one, could not agree more. Recently, the United Nations Youth Association held its 44thÂ annual youth conference in Adelaide, and I had the pleasure of closing the conference and accepting the Youth Declaration. It is on this topic that I would like to speak today.

The United Nations Youth Associationâor UNYAâis a national, community based organisation that aims to increase youth awareness and participation in international issues and political processes. UNYA is one of the only Australian youth organisations that is run entirely by youth for youth, and it has been broadening horizons for almost 40 years. The major aim of UNYA is to inspire young people to adopt the ideals and objectives of the United Nations, recognising it as the only global organisation that maintains the hope of world peace. UNYA places school students at the centre of the intrigue and excitement of international affairs in mock sessions of United Nations bodies. It exposes them to world-class speakers on a myriad of topics and provides social events to allow young people to develop their skills both educationally and socially.

The UNYA XLIV National Youth Conference brought together over 130 senior secondary school and tertiary students from around Australia and New Zealand for an exciting week of discussion, debate, negotiation and public speaking in Adelaide. Delegates to the conference had the opportunity to listen to a variety of speakers on a range of current domestic and international issues. Ideas were then discussed in smaller workshop sessions, where delegates were able to voice their opinions in a smaller setting and listen to the opinions of other delegates. The final result was the 2005 Youth Declaration. The Youth Declaration from each national youth conference is a concrete outcome which can then be distributed to government and other youth networks. This Youth Declaration is a collective vision for humanityâs future.

The 2005 Youth Declaration covers a range of issues, including human rights, international security and terrorism, globalisation and technology, Australia and the Pacific, economic sustainability, environmental sustainability, youth affairs and empowerment, education, and Indigenous Australians. Some of the 2005 resolutions are that the detention of asylum seekers should be solely for the purpose of essential security checks and identification; that international security is best promoted by international cooperation and multilateralism, which reinforces the importance of international laws and normative standards; and that voluntary student unionism will have alarming effects in terms of reducing vital funds required for the provision of services. These are just a few of the resolutions in the 2005 declaration.

The declaration is available on the UNYA web site, and I would like to encourage all of my colleagues on both sides of the House to take the time to read the document and to listen to the voice of our youth. I believe that UNYA should be commended for their role in educating and empowering young people to express their views. I would like to congratulate all of the participants in the UNYA XLIV National Youth Conference. I thank them not just for their attendance and for their participation but also for turning their thoughts and their efforts to improving both our community and our world. I think we would be a much better place if more of society stopped to do this more regularly.

I would like to acknowledge and congratulate Mr Travers Mcleod, who is the past national president of the United Nations Youth Association of Australia. I would also like to acknowledge Mr Alex Rafolowicz, who is the South Australian state president and who does a fantastic job locally. I would especially like to pay tribute to the 2005 conference convenor from South Australia, Penelope Wells. I know that Penelope and her team worked extremely hard to ensure that the Adelaide conference was a great success.

In closing, I would like to commend to this House the United Nations Youth Association and in particular their Youth Declaration. I encourage all members of both houses of this parliament to familiarise themselves with the 2005 Youth Declaration and its contents. The youth of today need a voice and we all must stop and listen to it. UNYA has provided that voice and I think we all have a duty to pay it some attention. I encourage you all to have a read.

talker.name: Billson, Bruce, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary (Foreign Affairs) and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs)
talker.name: Mr BILLSON

talk.start.para: âMr Acting Deputy Speaker, it has been a little whileâand I am sure you have probably missed itâsince I last spoke about the Scoresby Freeway. I, along with the community that I represent, have been going through a grieving phase. We had such optimism and such an opportunity to make sure that the south-east of the great city of Melbourneâthe great metropolisâhad the same access to key arterial road infrastructure, on the same terms, as those to the north and the west of our city. But, alas, after fantastic leadership by the Howard government and more than half a billion dollars of funding assistance being made available, and after the Bracks government made the bold promise, as has been widely publicised and which will never be forgotten, that there would be no tolls on the Scoresby Freeway, our citizens are facing having tolls for quite a period of time.

speech.para: The federal funding is still sitting there, so if the Bracks government comes to its senses and recognises its dire political circumstances in Victoria as a consequence of these kinds of broken promises, it can do the right thing and come back to the agreement that was signed and the undertaking that was given to the citizens of not only the south-east but the eastern suburbs of Melbourne. It is a shame, though, that on top of that hardship, there is now further neglect. It is now called EastLink, a spunky, flashy new name. They are talking about engineering marvels in an attempt to mask the basic deceptionâthe undermining of our economic prosperity. As interesting as all the bridges and the engineering marvels are, our people know what they were promised and they know what they are not getting. It is now called EastLink; the name change seems to mask its dark history.

EastLink is also reflecting further disappointment. Labor members at a state and federal level had something to say about the backflip of the Bracks government. They knew that this was not what their taxpayers and their community wanted. If you look along the length of the freeway to the north, there is an interchange that was provided as an enhancement to the original projectâsome could say a pay-off to the citizens in that part of the project area for the hardship of paying tolls. So there was some slight gain for a generation of toll pain. Then you look in the middle of the freeway and to the Dandenong community. To the credit of the Labor advocates in that area, who were also so appalled and had long known the hardship that the tolling reverse would provide, they managed to get a Dandenong bypass.
