So they actually got an outcome in return for the pain and in return for the deception.

However, if you look down southâdown to the community that I representâwhat have the Labor members down our way secured from this horrendous backflip, this political deception? Absolutely nothing. Nothing has been delivered. There has been no compensatory project to reflect the hardship that is being imposed.
Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI am pleased that my Labor colleagues from my state are as appalled as I am, and I thank them for their interjection supporting how appalled my citizens are. But what a vivid contrast. The noise and the excitement that we see in this chamber are in vivid contrast to the silence, the neglect, the complete indifference that the state Labor members in the community that I represent have shown with regard to our communityâs interests. They have not stood up and said that the Rutherford Road onramp should be built. It would give the commercial area to the north of Frankston, around the Seaford-Carrum Downs area, toll-free access to an alternative route to the Frankston Freeway. That has long been identified as being necessary by the chambers of commerce, Frankston City, the businesses that operate in that area, and the residential community, which has industrial traffic running past St Anneâs Primary School and its urban neighbourhoods. They were all looking to get an onramp onto the Frankston Freeway. What did they get? Nothingâabsolutely nothing.

speech.para: I mentioned interest in the Dandenong bypass. Did we get any mention of interest in the Frankston bypass? No. There was no effort, no voice, no advocacy, no action, no interest from the state Labor members of parliament down in our part of the world, in the most disgusting, diabolical political betrayal that anyone in my lifetime can remember. The consequences and the costs of this will be carried by my community into the next generation. We will have to try to attract investment, attract people to our region, knowing that we have one hand tied behind our backs, because to use the arterial road infrastructure in our part of the city comes at a price.

However, if you want to use the arterial road infrastructure to the north and the west, there are no tolls. There is a lack of consistency; there is a lack of voice. To the north of the project and to the centre of the project, there are some compensatory projects being achieved by Labor members of parliament who actually listened to their consciences, who knew that Labor have betrayed their citizens. But down in the south, what have we achieved? Our state Labor members of parliamentâwith no voice, no interest, no leadership, no advocacyâhave achieved nothing in return for a generation of tolls. They stand condemned. As far as I am concerned, and I believe as far as the community is concerned, the state election cannot come around soon enough, because our community needs strong advocates. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: F3 Freeway-New England Highway Road Link

talk.start.para: âI listened with great interest to the member for Dunkleyâs spin on the relationship between the Commonwealth and the states when it comes to road funding. Let me use an example in my own electorate to put a different perspective on the debate. Where the F3 Freeway northbound ends, a crisis begins. For the last 17 years, first as a councillor and more recently as a local member, I have been fighting to have funded the construction of a road link between the end of the F3 Freeway and the New England Highway north of Branxton. When I was elected in 1996, that project was on track. The route selection process had been undertaken and a funding commitment had been given. Alas, in the 1996 budgetâHowardâs first budget; it is now historyâwe encountered some significant budget cuts which put back this very important road project by many years.

speech.para: In more recent times I had become more hopeful that the project would finally proceed. Why? One, because it is no longer just a wish of the local community; it has become a necessity. Traffic movements through the townships of Cessnock and Maitland, and a number of smaller communities in between, have just become intolerable. The New England Highway between Newcastle and Singleton in the Upper Hunter is like Parramatta Road at peak hour each morning and each afternoon. It is becoming a crisis and it is time the Commonwealth made a decent commitment to funding of the project.

What worries me at the moment, and what causes me to address the issue again today, is a recent piece of correspondence I received from the then parliamentary secretary for roads, Mr Cobb, who indicated to me in response to questions I put to him in this place that they are reviewing the cost of the project and, to use his term, âsubstantial overrunsâ are expectedâin other words, the cost seems to have significantly blown out. Why should we not expect it to blow out, given the significant delays we have had in Commonwealth commitment over the course of the last 10 years?

The last estimate of this project was in the order of $345 million. The suggestion is that that cost may have close to doubled in recent years. The government claim to be committed to the project. They allocated some $253 million in the AusLink document but are of course scrapping the national highway project of which this road link is a part. As a consequence of that, they are now saying that the state must make a contribution. Maybe that is fair enough. They are saying, âWe are now going to put Commonwealth money into what were traditionally state projects, and the quid pro quo is that we expect the states to put money into projects which were traditionally the responsibility of the Commonwealth.â But whether that is a fair proposition or not depends, I suppose, on the ratio of the funding.

People are speculating that at $345 million it was reasonable for the state government to make a contribution of some $100 million to make it up to the $345 million or so required under the latest estimate. But if it is true that the cost has blown out to some $600 million then of course the state of New South Wales will not have the capacity to fund any more than $100 million. Of course it will not. So the Commonwealth cannot claim to have a solid commitment to the link between the F3 Freeway and the New England Highway while its commitment is stuck at some $253 million. It must review that commitment. Even more important, it must not only show a commitment in the AusLink white paper but also make a commitment in the forward estimates. Unfortunately, in the May budget of this year there was no such commitment. Given the budget goes out four forward years, are we, as constituents of the Hunter, then to understand that the Howard government has no real funding commitment for this project for the next four years? I hope not.

I call upon the government to, at the completion of the review of the costing, up the ante on this project and deliver to the Hunter what is the most important road transport infrastructure project we will probably ever encounter. Of course, the project has the unanimous support of all the regionâs mayors. There is no parochialism here. They agree that this is too important a project to be delayed any further. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker Causley, you will know what email is. You will probably even know what eBay is. But I wonder if you know what e-research is. E-research is the latest way that James Cook University in Townsville is expanding the horizons and the collaborative research that it does without anyone leaving an office. It is just truly amazing. I was able to go to James Cook University last week and open the information technology laboratories there. E-research is part of these new laboratories and their facilities. It is an amazing technology that allows the university to be a major player in developing the tools, the methods and the culture of e-research. What that means is that very large amounts of data indeed, no matter where it is in the world, can be linked together, manipulated and transferred across long distances and on advanced networks.

speech.para: James Cook is currently connected to the world on a one-gigabit data stream link, which enables it to be involved in all the supercomputing around the world. Indeed one of the projects that I saw was a collaborative project between scientists in Townsville and scientists at Harvard University in the United States. But scientists can be anywhere. They can be in the next room or in the next country or across the world. What e-research enables you to do is promote interdisciplinary research from different fieldsâlike engineering, mathematics, computer science and information technologyâand combine all of those to solve challenging problems in things like biology and biomedicine.

In the IT school at James Cook University, I was able to see leading health researchers and doctors developing new methods of predicting diseases before they happen, but using computer science, using e-research, and manipulating large amounts of data that is held on file to enable these diagnostic tools to work. I have been a strong advocate and supporter of James Cook Universityâ

talk.start.para: âAnd a very good one, at that.

âThank you. I visit the campus on a regular basis. However, each time I visit the facilities, it never ceases to amaze me how much world-class research is being done there, out in the regions of Australia. It is a great credit to our regional universities that they are able to stay up there with the rest of the world. James Cook certainly continues to forge ahead, particularly over the last five years as the result of a number of new degrees and new backing from the government.

speech.para: Last month Brendan Nelson, the Minister for Education, Science and Training, and I had the privilege to officially open the new $6.2 million Rehabilitation Sciences Centre. It is the next link in the chain of medicine at JCU, with the medical degree, the pharmacy degree, the nursing degree and now the allied sciences degrees. The state-of-the-art facility was made possible by a grant from the Australian government. The centre plays an important role in teaching the physiotherapists, speech pathologists and sports science graduates of tomorrow and also complements the universityâs medical school that was established in the year 2000 and will graduate its first doctors on 15 December this year. That will be a mighty proud day for all of us who had a hand in establishing that medical school.

One of the most important reasons why I have been a strong advocate of the university providing more health degrees is that it is vital in addressing the shortage of health professionals in North Queensland. The statistics have shown over and over again that people who study in the region are more likely to stay and work in the region when they have completed their studies. That has certainly been the experience of James Cook. It is all about investing in our future. That is why the Australian government has committed a record $7.8 billion in funding for higher education this financial year alone. Next year I will be pleased to see the start of the new veterinary science degree and also the tropical agriculture science degree. That will also link into the medical faculty. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âLast week the St George district lost a legend. The chief executive of the St George District Rugby League Football Club, Robert Stone, died at the age of 49 years. Robert Stone was a St George Rugby League great. Robert was known for his courage and toughness on the field, captaining St George in 1984, having played in the 1977 and 1979 premiership teams. Robert played 283 games for St George, a figure exceeded only by famous St George players Norm Provan and Billy Smith. As chief executive of the St George Football Club, he was instrumental in the St George Illawarra Dragons returning to their famous Kogarah Jubilee home ground. Many professional footballers today owe their success to Robert Stone as a coach, mentor or development officer, and many people owe their success to his skills as a teacher.

speech.para: From an early age Robert was a role model for others. I grew up around the corner from Robert. We played for the same Blakehurst Rugby Union Football Club, but Robert was two years older. Through representative selection, Robertâs toughness became known throughout the district. I can recall vividly when I was about 16 years of age being at a dance at the Carrs Park swimming pool when a group of my friends and I were surrounded by other boys from a neighbouring schoolâsome brandishing weapons. I remember to this day Robert, who was just two years older, coming to stand beside us. In his calm and relaxed style he simply inquired, with wry humour, âIs there a problem here?â His presence, size and reputation immediately resolved that situation. It was a source of enormous pride to see our mate achieve such success on the Rugby League playing field but, despite his status as a local hero, Robert always had time to have a yarn with his mates in the local area.

I have always enjoyed Robertâs company immensely, but must admit that I did not always enjoy the following morning. It was not commonly known that Robert was a deep thinker and had an earthy wisdom. During policy debates within the Labor Party, if I thought things were going a bit way outâas I must admit they can do from time to timeâI would try to bring them back to reality, as you may recall, Mr Deputy Speaker McMullan, by quoting the Robert Stone view of life. Indeed, Mark Latham played on that fact on the evening before his leadership ballot. When I informed him that I was still undecided later that evening, he was prepared to take a gamble and said to me, âWhy donât you ask Stoney?â The rest of that story is now history.

Robert literally had the ability to mix with all ranks, from a kid in a local football team to the Prime Minister. Indeed, on the day that Robert died, I received a phone call from the Prime Minister expressing his personal grief and asking me for the details of Robertâs family so that he could convey his personal sympathy. Robert brought his courage to his fight against cancer. He was privileged to have the love and support of his family. He was nurtured to the last by his wife, Anne, daughters, Melissa and Belinda, and son, Michael. He was supported by his mother, Iris, his elder brother, Peter, and Anneâs family. The entire St George Illawarra Dragons were first class in their support of Robert during, in particular, his final months. Danny Robinson, Peter Doust and others can take enormous pride in the care they provided to our great mate and a great Australian.

talk.start.para: âToday I would like to pay tribute to a group of my constituents who recently journeyed overseas to pay tribute to 30 Queensland police officers killed on active duty during World War I. Current serving Queensland police officers Sergeant Paul Ruge and Sergeant Mal Nicholls, both based in Gladstone, and Senior Sergeant Ian Gall, also based in Gladstone, retraced the steps of these little-recognised Queensland police officers who gave their lives for their country.

speech.para: For 18 months, Sergeant Ruge researched and planned a battlefields memorial journey to visit the graves of, or the memorials for, the officers who were killed in World War I. While the names of these police officers are recorded in the Queensland police honour roll, and as they are also acknowledged on Police Remembrance Day, there has been no official commemorative visit to their graves or memorials until this journey. We must bear in mind that the police officers who were killed in battle were in what was classified at that time as âexempt occupationsâ during World War I as their service required them at home. Yet, despite this, 30 men chose to take up voluntary active service in the name of defending their country.

The groupâs visit coincided with the 90th anniversary of the landing at Gallipoli and took around five weeks to complete. It was entirely self-funded. The group visited memorials at Gallipoli in Turkey, Alexandria in Egypt, Haifa in Israel, Hampshire in England, the Somme and Flanders in France and Belgium, and Dessel in Germany. At each gravesite or memorial, Sergeant Ruge, Sergeant Nichols and Senior Sergeant Gall laid a wreath in memory of the sacrifice of the officers and read out a eulogy on their life and their service during the war.

The highlight of the trip was the very moving dawn service held at Gallipoli on Anzac Day, and members were honoured to volunteer their services as marshals at that event. They were particularly honoured that our Minister for Veteransâ Affairs singled them out from the crowd and took time to congratulate them for their efforts. Sergeant Ruge also laid a wreath at Lone Pine on Anzac Day, together with the UN Police Association president, as a member of the UN Police Association of Australia. A wreath was also laid at the Mennen Gate in Belgium on behalf of fallen officers.

A very positive outcome was the righting of a great injustice to one of the soldiers of the First World War, a police officer, Private John Graham, who won the distinguished conduct medal in action as a stretcher-bearer at Pozieres in 1916. Private Grahamâs headstone did not recognise him as being the holder of a DCM until representations were made by Sergeant Ruge to the Commonwealth War Graves Commission on his return to Australia. Private Graham is now to have the DCM inscribed on his headstone, almost 90 years after his death, so that he will be accorded the honour in death that he was denied in life.

Photographs of the entire journey and research on each officer will be incorporated in a booklet to be presented to the Queensland Police Museum. This will enhance the historical records of the military service of the 30 officers who were killed in action.

Sergeant Ruge himself is a veteran of overseas service, having been one of three Queensland police officers to serve as a member of the fifth Australian contingent of Australian Federal Police to East Timor in 2000-01. He was station commander at Hera and Metinaro police districts in East Timor during his tour of duty. Sergeant Ruge and Sergeant Nichols are also former members of the Australian Army ReserveâSergeant Ruge for 20 years and Sergeant Nichols for 10 years. Both are members of the RSL; Sergeant Ruge is also a member of the UN Police Association of Australia.

All those who undertook this historic trip deserve sincere congratulations. I commend Sergeants Ruge and Nichols for their commitment to commemorating the service of those brave policemen who went before them.

talk.start.para: âAustralia currently has the lowest rate of industrial disputes in decades. Why, then, is this parliament contemplating changing our industrial legislation in the most massive way? The answer is: pure ideology. The ideology of an extreme free market economy, an ideology that has no basis in empirical evidence before any Australian voter or any Australian parliamentarian, now rules both houses.

speech.para: Recently we have had insulting remarks by the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and the Treasurer to various leaders of the Anglican and Catholic churches, telling them to keep out of areas that the government feels they should not have responsibility for, such as the rights of workers. The Treasurer said that the Primate of the Anglican Church of Australia was no industrial relations expert. I feel like that American senator; I feel like saying, âIâve met industrial relations experts, and, Treasurer, you donât appear to be one.â

The very strongly held views of the churches on peopleâs rights are quite understandable. Indeed, in this chamber, we have recently had paeans of deserved praise for the late His Holiness John Paul II. Pope John Paul II, during a visit to Australia in 1986, met factory workers in Parramatta. This will interest the member for Parramatta. His Holiness John Paul II said:

quote.para: Australia also has a long and proud tradition of settling industrial disputes and promoting cooperation by its almost unique system of arbitration and conciliation.
This system has helped to defend the rights of workers and promote their well being, while at the same time taking into account the needs and the future of the whole community.

speech.para: No wonder Cardinal Pell has recently said of the current industrial relations legislation:

quote.para: I think thereâs an even greater need for wisdom and magnanimity from the Prime Minister ...
Weâve had a long period of prosperity in Australia and I think that means that the necessity for radical change needs to be established.
The disparity between the rich and the poor is of some concern, but it is different if the minimum wage is still rising.

speech.para: We know that, in some areas, already these changes are being anticipated by some people. The other day the Financial Review had a very interesting vignette about Jesters pies and Bakers Delight cashing out the hourly rate of workers so that they would have no annual leave at all. To quote Dominic Panetta, a franchisee at Jesters pies:

quote.para: If they want to take a holiday, they donât get paid.

speech.para: What about the area of part-time students studying with the approval of the employee, something that I would have thought was important in the skilling up of Australia? Let us look at a couple of scenarios that will take place in light of the fact that study will not be part of the five core principles of this governmentâs extreme free market industrial relations legislation. Employees who wish to study to further their careers are generally given the option to study by their employer and, in the majority of businesses, are encouraged to do so. There is generally no compulsion from employers to do so; rather, it is up to the employee to take up the option. A part-time student studying postgraduate business/finance is faced with two subjects per semester at a cost of $1,750 per subject for two semesters per year. Depending on which university you go to, that cost is around the average. It therefore costs about $3,500 per semester or $7,000 per year. Under current working arrangements for industries such as accounting and finance, the employer will pay these costs upon the employee achieving a pass mark.

Time off is given for the student employee. For example, provision for up to five hours a week study leave is contained in clause 14 in the section on study assistance on page 47 of the certified agreement covering members of parliament. Generally two weeks study leave with pay for the examination period is guaranteed, under clause 15.

Yet under the proposed legislation, students studying part time would have to meet all their own costs and have no time off for study leave. Study is not part of the five core principles of the Howard governmentâs industrial relations law. These changes may well be the case in a small accounting or financial services companies that have up to 20 employees. Employees will be forced to use their annual leave for examination periods.

This whole fraudulent industrial relations legislation, based on no empirical evidence, is driven by an extreme free market mentality, by the mentality of Margaret Thatcher, who said, âThere is no such thing as society; there are only individuals.â (Time expired) Â

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker Baldwin, allow me to congratulate you on so competently occupying this high office in the Main Committee. I am privileged to represent one of the fastest growing areas in Australia, and I refer of course to the Sunshine Coast. The population growth on the Sunshine Coast between 1998 and 2003 was 3.53 per cent, which makes it the third-fastest growing area in Australia behind Mandurah, 74 kilometres south of Perth, with 4.02 per cent, and the Gold Coast-Tweed area, with 3.67 per cent. One of the issues that levels of governmentâstate, local and federalâhave is to make sure that the infrastructure for rapidly growing areas like the Sunshine Coast keeps up with the increasing population. Some people consider that over the next 10 to 15 years the population of the Sunshine Coast will grow from some 260,000 to more than half a million people. That of course places great challenges on all levels of government to make sure that the infrastructure that people need and deserve is there to meet the requirements of our growing population.

speech.para: I want to praise the Australian government for taking the important step of recognising Australiaâs sea change phenomenon and ensuring assistance for the scores of local governments that are affected by this great change in how we live and where we live in Australia. High numbers of Australians are choosing to shift houses to live in coastal communities, and the resulting unexpected and unplanned-for booms are placing great challenges on infrastructure and, I might add, on all levels of government. This is one of the major issues confronting Australia in 2005. I believe that, as people continue to move to these very desirable parts of the country, this is going to be an ongoing challenge for governments, regardless of their political complexion.

The issues associated with sea change were discussed recently at a meeting of the Council of Local Government and Planning Ministers in Melbourne. The federal Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads attended that meeting, along with the National Sea Change Task Force chairman, my good friend Councillor Joe Natoli, the Mayor of the Maroochy Shire Council on the Sunshine Coast.

We on the Sunshine Coast need to work together, regardless of our political party and regardless of our level of government, to make sure that we continue to receive our share of infrastructure improvements from all levels of government. The Australian government is prepared to play its part. I must say that I have been concerned at the lack of attention to this important matter on the part of the Beattie state Labor government. The government of Queensland has a number of Labor representatives on the Sunshine Coast, and it really is important that they sit down and look at what is required for our local communities. I anticipate actually having a meeting of all levels of government representatives on the Sunshine Coast so that we can make sure that we work together, because we can achieve so much more through cooperation rather than confrontation.
A division having been called in the House of Representativesâ

interrupt.para: Sitting suspended from 11.40 am to 11.53 am

talk.start.para: âIn the time remaining to me I want to say how amazed I was to find that the opposition in the Senate are actually objecting to the new allocation of questions to reflect the fact that the Australian people chose to give the coalition a majority in the Senate. Despite the fact that the coalition has a majority in the Senate, the opposition still gets to ask very many more questions each time the Senate sits than does the government. An equitable proposition would be for the number of questions allocated to senators in accordance with the proportions that the parties are in the parliament, but this never happens. What happens, though, in the main chamber of the House of Representatives is that at question time we have questions asked alternately by members on the opposition side and on the government side. When there are Independents they of course have to share the opposition allocation of questions. So in the Senate the coalition is being incredibly more generous to the opposition than is really appropriate.

speech.para: Also, of course, the position of Deputy President of the Senate could well have been taken by the coalition and, in my view, should have been taken by the coalition following the fact that the Australian people reduced the opposition parties to a minority situation in the Australian Senate. I think it is tragic when the Labor Party huffs and puffs and makes such an unreasonable argument. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âAs we start a new parliamentary session, I think it is appropriate to review what the parliament is about and to review the governmentâs agenda and the direction they are taking Australia. This is a new era in Australian politics, with the Howard government having control of both houses of parliament. It places a great responsibility on them, and they need to be very cognisant of the fact that they are the government for the whole of Australia. They must at no stage forget that there are many people who did not vote for them and who disagree vehemently with what they stand for and some of the policies that they will be pursuing. At the same time, they need to try to take those people with them.

speech.para: With the government having control of both houses of the parliament, we have got to watch their agenda. I believe that the governmentâs agenda is quite reactionary and has the potential to impact on many Australians. I have always believed that, on any issue, the best outcome is achieved by consensus and cooperation; by inclusion, not exclusion. I do not believe that exclusion is a healthy approach but, unfortunately, the Howard government appear not to share this belief that inclusion is in the best interests of the Australian people. Rather, they have adopted an aggressive, divisive agenda based on exclusion, alienation and the creation of in-groups and out-groups within our society.

Earlier this morning, the member for Port Adelaide made a very good speechâone that I am quite happy to associate myself with. In my three-minute statement I raised the issue of TAFE and the changes that are going to take place there. We need to look at some of the things that have been happening within Australia. You only have to look at university students and see how upset they are about the changes in the area of voluntary student unionism and the impact that they believe the changes in that area will have on their education and on their ability to access all the things that they need as university students.

The sale of Telstra is on the agenda, and I see that that has caused divisions even within the government parties. Once again, there are going to be some people who benefit quite significantly from the sale of Telstra, but there are going to be many people who are going to be disadvantaged by it. It really worries me when you have a situation where some people are going to do very nicely and other people are going to be alienated by a decision of the government.

An area that is very close to my heart is the disability support pension. Before coming into parliament I worked with people with disabilities for some 13 years, helping those people find work. I know that the greatest thing that you can do to help a person with a disability to find work is to create a secure environment for them to look for work. What will happen under this governmentâs legislation will be the stigmatisation of certain people with certain disabilities, including people with back injuries, because that is something about which there already are some stereotypes. Another area of concern is the supporting parents benefit; and I cannot for a moment leave out the changes that are going to happen in the industrial relations area. I feel that significant groups of people in our community will be disadvantaged, and that is not what the government should be about. It should be governing for the whole of Australia.

On Tuesday, 9 August I became a grandmother. I have a grandson, Samuel Lindsay Hall, and I worry about the kind of world that he is going into. I want him to be able to enjoy the lifestyle of the Australia that I grew up in, not the Australia that Australia is becomingâone of division. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Baldwin)âThe memberâs time has expired, and congratulations on the birth of your grandson. I now call the member for Forde.

âI would also like to congratulate the member for Shortland on the birth of her new grandson; there is nothing greater than grandchildren. I would also like to reassure the member for Shortland about the Queensland uni students and say to her that they are in good hands. I will give the member for Shortland the other side of the story. Recently in my electorate, when uni first began, I had a parent and a student come and see me because they were from a low-income family and they could not pay their upfront union feesâabout $400âand they were not allowed to use any textbooks or any equipment in the university. If you call that a fair systemâwhere you are not allowed to start your education because you have not paid the union some duesâthat is the reason why we have to seriously look at that issue, so that low-income people are not disadvantaged by that particular impost.

speech.para: Today I stand up because I would like to talk about a presentation I recently hadâthe Forde Community Awards. I hosted a morning tea to thank and honour the special local residents of my community who voluntarily give so much of their time and effort to help our community be a better place to live in. These awards were established in 1996 as a way for the community to say thank you to the voluntary workers who are the backbone of our community. These are the people who, through helping others and contributing to local events, give our society its heart and soul and who set an example of the way we should all like to be.

It is through partnerships and building stronger communities that we begin to tackle some of the tough social problems and to work towards long-term solutions. Governments cannot do it alone, and history has taught us that simply throwing money at social problems does not resolve them. But I have great faith that by building stronger local communities and by fostering a belief that we all can do our little bit to help others, we will begin to turn things around. We can build an Australian tradition of community services and lending a hand to those in need, and that is exactly what these awards are all about.

As I continue to work with our local community groups, I am heartened and inspired by the many dedicated local residents. They are the heart and soul of our community, as I said before. I know that these big-hearted constituents never sought or expected any public recognition for the years of hard work that they gave so freely and for the good of others, and they never needed to be formally thanked. Nevertheless, I believe it is important that we acknowledge and recognise their strong service to our community and hold them as an example for future generations to aspire to. The Forde Community Awards are just one small way that I can recognise and reward service to our community.

I would like to take the time to record their names in this House today, starting with Victoria Laurenzi from Meadowbrook. She is a young lady with a very bright future. She is a member of the Beaudesert Shire Youth Council. She was recently awarded the Beaudesert Youth Citizen of the Year for her contribution to the community. She is also involved in Rotary, Red Cross and the local Police Citizens Youth Club, just to name a few. An award was also given to George and Louisa Harch. George and Louisa have been part of our Beenleigh community for as long as anyone can remember. They received this award for their tireless efforts to Beenleigh senior citizens, Meals on Wheels, the Lutheran womenâs fellowship group and the thrift shops. They entertain at the Beenleigh nursing home and they also contribute largely to the success of our Beenleigh historical village. Our community really felt recently for George at the great loss of Louisa, and we wish him every strength for the future.

Brian Wecker received his award for the work he does for the disadvantaged at the Sunnybank Indoor Bowls Club. He raises money, through the bowls club, for the Royal Brisbane Hospitalâs childrenâs burns unit and the cancer research unit. I was delighted to present an award to Barry Fitton of Canungra. I have seen first-hand the work that he does, and he is a quiet achiever. He receives this award for his service to ex-service men and women for the past 10 years. Barry organises monthly functions for elderly ex-service people. He is currently secretary of the Canungra RSL. He organises all of our celebrations for Anzac Day, Veterans Day and Remembrance Day. He is involved in all aspects of veteran community support, and I congratulate him on this award.

Albert and Pauline Pryor of Beaudesert received an award for their years of dedication to the Woodhill Rural Fire Brigade. Keith Reinke of Beaudesert received his award for his dedication to the Beaudesert Rotary club. Keith makes wheelchairs out of bikes and he sends them to the Asia and Pacific regions. His latest project is getting a hydro pool for the sick and elderly in our electorate. I wish him well with that. Leslie Turner of Eagleby is involved in Neighbourhood Watch, Eagleby police, and he is a liaison officer with the Eagleby garden club. He is a great person; he always has a smile on his face and gives a helping hand. Delaune Pollard has been recognised for her work with the aged. She has written a book to help people with dementia, Midlife challenges. She is also chair of the regional disability council. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âNo doubt you, Mr Deputy Speaker Baldwin, along with other members of the chamber will recall that on 15 July there was imagery of the Minister for Education, Science and Training, Brendan Nelson, sitting on nuclear waste drums at Lucas Heights and announcing that the government intended to site a nuclear waste facility in the Northern Territory. He proposed one of three sitesâone south of Katherine, one to the north-east of Alice Springs at Harts Range and one to the north-west of Alice Springs off the Yuendumu road.

speech.para: This was done without even so much as a by-your-leave. There was no discussion and no negotiation; there was no information given to the Northern Territory community. No discussion was undertaken with the Northern Territory government. Indeed, the Northern Territory government heard of this as a result of a press release and a fax released at the time that the minister was making the statement.

As you can imagine, Mr Deputy Speaker, this has outraged the community of the Northern Territory, not least because, prior to the last federal election, the people of the Northern Territory were given an absolute categorical assuranceâan âabsolute categorical assuranceâ, in the words of Senator Ian Campbell, Minister for the Environment and Heritageâthat no nuclear waste facility would be built in the Northern Territory.

Had the minister said at the time that there would be a nuclear waste facility at one of three sites in the Northern Territory, I can guarantee one thing: the member for Solomon would not be here today as the member for Solomon. He absolutely would not be here today. I would even go so far as to say that Senator Scullion would be very close to not being here today either. Such is the strength of feeling in the Northern Territory community about, firstly, the proposition that there should be a nuclear waste site in the Northern Territory and, secondly, the lies that have been told by this federal governmentâassurances given, guarantees that there would be no nuclear waste facility.

We are told that this is safe. All the experts say that this is safe and we do not have to worry about it. They say that it is low-level wasteâmaybe with some intermediate-level waste. Later we are told, âWeâll be bringing stuff back from the UK and France, which we will have to store in drums.â It will be there for yearsâhundreds of years. There is no reference to disposal, no explanation as to what is going to happen to this stuff in the long term. We are told that we will have one of these three sites in the Northern Territory.

Last week, Minister Macfarlane said that it is treated in such a way and stored in such a way at present that it presents no danger to the environment or the population around it. If that is the case, leave it where it bloody well is. Leave it at Lucas Heights. The people at Lucas Heights say they are prepared to take it. Alternatively, put it in New South Wales at one of the many sites which have been identified by the governmentâs own national site advisory committee, the committee which was established by Peter McGauran when he was minister for science. We have no informationâor not much informationâabout who was on this committee, but it produced a list. Not one of the three sites identified in the Northern Territory was identified as suitable, and two of them were not even on the list. What we have from the government, from this committee, is a list of sites in New South Wales that are deemed suitable by these experts to store nuclear waste. Does it surprise that there is even a site in the ACT?

Let me take you through a few of the sites, Mr Deputy Speaker Baldwin. I am sure you will be keen to hear about them. I think one of them might be at Singleton. There is certainly one at Denman. It is deemed most suitable. There are 460 hectares. There is Bogan Gate, which is near Parkesâ1,000 hectares, most suitable. There are 7,400 hectares near Narranderaâmost suitable. There is Waggaâ1,688 hectares, most suitable. There is Deniliquinâ1,081 hectares, most suitable. And then there is Mount Reedy near Canberraâjust down the road, near Mount Majura. There are eight hectares there, and it says âsuitableâ.

Not one of these sites has been considered. The government has taken the soft cop. It has said, âWe can do this in the Northern Territory because we have Commonwealth land, Defence land. We can take away the decision making in the Northern Territory community about land management.â The government will take away decision making to do with the Northern Territoryâjust as it has subsequently done over the issue of uranium mining.
We are not going to stand for it. We will not tolerate it. Just so that the House can be informed, I seek leave to table the document headed âShortlist with NSAC CommentsâFinalâ.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to talk about the fact that the Queensland state Labor government continues to ignore its responsibilities to provide adequate road transport infrastructure and adequate public transport infrastructure to the residents of my electorate of Moncrieff and, more broadly, the residents of the Gold Coast. I have spoken on many occasions about the fact that the Gold Coast is the fastest-growing city in the country. For the last 25 years the Gold Coast has grown at a faster rate than anywhere else in Australia, and it is projected that for the next 25 years the Gold Coast will continue to grow at a faster rate than anywhere else in the country. Notwithstanding this fact, the Beattie Labor government continues to shirk its responsibilities on a daily basis with regard to the provision of adequate road transport and adequate public transport. I must highlight the absolute lack of good representation from the state Labor members on the Gold Coast. They are colloquially known as âthe silent sevenâ because of the fact that they are either unwilling or unable to speak up on behalf of the residents and constituents in their respective state electorates.

speech.para: One of the latest tricks that the Beattie state Labor government are getting up to with regard to the provision of road transport and roads generally across the Gold Coast is to continually come forward with proposals to part-fund the construction of new roads or to part-fund the maintenance of roads or to part-fund the expansion of existing road corridors. But in each of these instances these are roads that are solely within the domain of state government jurisdiction. In each of these instances, it is the state government that should be providing all the funding for the construction of these roads. There is a line I often use which I think resonates with the community and which I believe underscores the principle at stake: if the federal government went to the Queensland state government and asked for partial funding for new defence ships, helicopters or aircraft, then it would be laughed out of town. Yet for some reason the Queensland state Labor government, with a very straight face, believe that they can go to the community and say, âWeâll part-fund this if only the federal government comes to the party.â The federal government does not directly fund state government controlled roads.

There is a deeper issue at the core of this, and that is the fact that, for every dollar that the Queensland state Labor government spends on roads, 67c comes from the Commonwealth government indirectly, through the money that we provide to the Queensland state government. This year the Queensland state government is running a $3 billion surplus. That $3 billion could be used to ease the traffic congestion that we have on the Gold Coast. In particular I say to those residents of my electorate that live in Nerang, Highland Park, Mudgeeraba and Carrara: the reason that you are suffering from poor traffic infrastructure and a poor road network is that the state Labor member Dianne Reilly, the state Labor member Robert Poole, the state Labor member for the Broadwater area, who is responsible for the traffic congestion around Frank Streetâthat is, Peta-Kaye Croftâand the state Labor Party member for Southport, Peter Lawlor, are all reluctant or unwilling to take the fight up to Peter Beattie, to put forward the case, on behalf of their residents and their constituents, about why the Queensland government must invest in more road transport infrastructure for the people of the Gold Coast.

Recently the Beattie Labor government made a big song and dance about the fact that it intends over the next 25 years to provide additional funding for infrastructure. The problem is that, when you compare the Gold Coast to Ipswich, Brisbane and the Sunshine Coast, when it comes to roads we come last. That is despite the fact that it is the fastest-growing region in the state. So the simple choice for all constituents is to put the truth to the lie currently being told that it is the federal government that is holding up road funding. The reality is that these are state government roads. The state government has a massive windfall surplus as a result of the GST. The federal government already indirectly contributes 67c in every dollar that the Queensland government puts into roads funding, and it is high time the state local Labor MPs stood up on behalf of their constituents and actually did something to make the lot of Gold Coast residents better. That is the reason they were elected, that is the job they have got to do and it is important they do it.

talk.start.para: âOver the weekend, on a spectacular Sydney winter day, I joined a group of bikers out at Krispy Kreme Doughnuts at Penrith for the annual blanket ride into Parramatta. In one of the great perks of officeâand I am not talking about the doughnutsâI got to jump on the back of a Harley and join an impressive convoy of bikes that rode down the freeway into Parramatta Town Hall square, all carrying blankets as donations for the growing number of homeless people in our local area. At Parramatta square, we joined many locals who had come together to acknowledge the crisis in accommodation faced by many Australians and to acknowledge the plight of the growing number of homeless people in our local community.

speech.para: The event in the square was organised by three of our community groups: Parramatta Mission, Anglicare and Street Level Christian Community. The blanket run was the brainchild of a Christian biker group called the Brotherhood, founded by Greg Hirst as the ministry arm to the Street Level Christian Community. Its purpose was to reach out to young people at risk. As well as running a successful drop-in centre in Pitt Street, Merrylands, the Brotherhood organise a blanket run and a Christmas toy run each year.

On any night, around 100,000 Australians are homeless or at risk of becoming homelessâmany on the street, some sleeping on the floor at relativesâ or friendsâ places and many more in crisis accommodation and shelters. For many Australians who think of homelessness in terms of the older men that they see sleeping in parks and under bridges, it would be a surprise to know that over half of those 100,000 people are femaleâsome 56 per cent. Few people realise that over one-third are under 25 years old and that two-thirds are under the age of 35. Only 14 per cent are over 45 and nearly 10 per cent are under the age of 12. The average age of homeless women or women at risk is only 30, and 33 for men. The highest users of crisis services are people aged just 18 and 19 years.

But these figures are not reflected by what we see in the streets. That is because some 1,200 agencies around the country provide services and assistance to people who are homeless or in danger of becoming homeless. These organisations are run by committed people in underresourced organisations who work both day and night making sure that as many people as possible have safe accommodation. There are thousands of people working to bring the most vulnerable people back into society as quickly as possible. There can be no question it is because of these people providing support at the early stages, working to reconnect people as quickly as possible before the secondary effects of homelessness set in, that we do not see a far greater number of people in our parks and under bridges. The community as a whole should be grateful for every one of these workers who choose to work in this area for the benefit of the greater community.

The Commonwealth government supports the work of these people through the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program, known as the SAAP agreement. The fourth agreement between the states expired on 1 July 2005. In late June, a three-month stopgap agreement was reached, but as of today there is still no agreement and one is not expected until 30 September. Meanwhile, thousands of community workers carry on, unsure of their status and unsure of their jobs, doing more and more with less and less in real terms. Despite evidence of a significant unmet need, the Commonwealth is not offering any new money, no increase above indexation, in spite of an evaluation in 2004 that showed that an increase of 15 per cent is needed just to hold services at current levelsâtoo little and alarmingly late.

This is a common story that surrounds this governmentâthe lateness of decisions concerning the funding of the community sector, and the exploitation of the commitment, generosity and goodwill of our most community-minded and compassionate citizens. It shows a lack of respect and appreciation for people who already work for less money than they could make elsewhere and who are already making sacrifices for the most vulnerable people in our society. They are people who have mortgages of their own and who really do not know what will happen to their jobs as of 30 September or what will happen to the people they work so hard to represent. It shows a complete lack of understanding of the role our community sector plays in holding an increasingly fractured community together. I urge the government to give real support to our community organisations, as they work for all of us in this vital area of homelessness in our community.

talk.start.para: âFor some time in my community there has been an issue that has created concern. It is in relation to some land that the Department of Defence is proposing to deal with because it really does not have any further Defence purpose. The land in question is Jezzine Barracks, which is basically on the foreshore in Townsville. It is the home of Australiaâs 11 Brigade, a reserve brigade which is going to move to Lavarack Barracks, home of Australiaâs 3rd Brigade. They will move to be with the Australian Regular Army. The land at Jezzine Barracks, which has been in Defence use for more than a century, will no longer be required for Defence purposes and Defence has to decide what it might do with the land. There are lots of options. There is a lot of concern in the community about the fact that this land, right on the foreshore, might in fact become a developerâs paradise. I think we all understand that, and certainly the government understands it. But it is disappointing to see an emotional debate going on in the community rather than a logical and rational debate. Part of that was illustrated by a story in yesterdayâs Townsville Bulletin, which led off with the words:

quote.para: An officer from the Australian Defence Force has been in town to start negotiations on the sell-off of Jezzine Barracks and Kissing Point.

speech.para: This is just patent rubbish. The journalist who wrote that should be ashamed of himself. He knows that there is no proposed sell-off of Jezzine Barracks or Kissing Pointânone. That was all explained to him, yet he writes an emotive line about Defence being in town to begin the negotiation to sell off the property. It is irresponsible. I do not normally rise in the parliament to be critical of a journalist. I work with journalists every day. But, gee, they have got to tell the truth. They cannot just go for a good headline.

There is further evidence that there could be no sell-off anyway, particularly of Kissing Point, because it is heritage listed. All of the fort area on the top of the headlandâquite a substantial area of landâis entered on the Commonwealth heritage register. It cannot be sold; it just canât. Yet we have the Townsville Bulletin saying that Defence is here to start the negotiations to sell it off. I would just ask the Bulletin to be more reasonable.
In todayâs Bulletin, the editorial writer notes:

quote.para: Mr Lindsay assures us that Kissing Point will not be lost to the community, but this is not an issue we can take on trust.

speech.para: The Bulletin are saying that they do not trust me. You have got a piece of land that is entered on the Commonwealth heritage register and that cannot be sold, and they are saying that they cannot trust me when I say it cannot be sold. I do not think it is a very intelligent editorial, with that sort of thing happening.

There are a number of stakeholders interested in this matter. I understand the communityâs concerns. What the government are doing, and what we have said all along, is this: we will establish a consultative group within Defenceâand that has been establishedâwho will consult widely with the community. As soon as they start the consultation process, the media in Townsville is saying that they are there to sell off the land. It is just not true. I can assure our community that groups like the North Queensland Military Museum, the RSL, the city councilâthose sorts of groupsâwill have full and open access to the consultative committee, and in fact the wider community of Townsville will have that access. I note that, before writing to other key stakeholders, the parliamentary secretary who is responsible for this process yesterday wrote to the Mayor of the Townsville City Council, Tony Mooney, extending to him the first invitation to join the consultative forum. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 16 November 2004:

item.para: How many Medicare services were provided during (a) 2002-2003, and (b) 2003-2004 in (i) Victoria, and (ii) the electoral division of Scullin.

How many Medicare services were provided during (a) 2002-2003, and (b) 2003-2004 in the postcode area (i) 3074, (ii) 3075, (iii) 3076, (iv) 3082, (v) 3083, (vi) 3087, (vii) 3088, (viii) 3089, (ix) 3090, (x) 3091, and (xi) 3752.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: Medicare bulk billing and related statistics by electoral division are available on a calendar year basis.

The smallest geographical area for which the department routinely produces statistics is by electoral division.Â The postcodes you have nominated are contained within or overlap the electorates of Scullin, Batman, Jagajaga and McEwen.Â The requested statistics cover each of these electorates.

item.para: and (2) The number of Medicare services provided in 2002, 2003 and 2004 in (i) Victoria, (ii) the electoral division of Scullin and (iii) other relevant electorates, is as follows:
Notes to the Statistics
The statistics relate to services that were rendered on a âfee-for-serviceâ basis for which benefits were processed by the Health Insurance Commission in 2002, 2003 and 2004.

Since the statistics sought relate to âservices provided in â¦â the statistics were compiled from Medicare data by servicing provider postcode.Â Medicare statistics by electorate published on the Department of Health and Ageing web site were compiled from patient enrolment postcode data.

In compiling the statistics, where a postcode overlapped electoral boundaries, the data were allocated to electorate using a concordance file derived from population census data.Â This can result in some data being erroneously allocated to an adjoining electorate.Â Data have been excluded if postcodes were not present on the concordance file.

* Caution should be exercised in interpreting Medicare statistics by region of provider.Â Electorates containing major hospitals and health facilities and electorates that encompass major regional centres will have higher rates of service provision.Â This explains the very high number of services provided in Jagajaga.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 16 November 2004:

item.para: How many Medicare services were provided per capita during (a) 2002-2003, and (b)Â 2003-2004 in (i) Victoria, and (ii) the electoral division of Scullin.

How many Medicare services were provided per capita during (a) 2002-2003, and (b)Â 2003-2004 in the postcode area (i) 3074, (ii) 3075, (iii) 3076, (iv) 3082, (v) 3083, (vi) 3087, (vii) 3088, (viii) 3089, (ix) 3090, (x) 3091, and (xi) 3752.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: Medicare bulk billing and related statistics by electoral division are available on a calendar year basis.

The smallest geographical area for which the department routinely produces statistics is by electoral division. The postcodes you have nominated are contained within or overlap the electorates of Scullin, Batman, Jagajaga and McEwen. The requested statistics cover each of these electorates.

item.para: and (2) The number of Medicare services provided per capita in 2002, 2003 and 2004 in (i) Victoria, (ii) the electoral division of Scullin and (iii) other relevant electorates, is as follows:

entry.para: MEDICARE - TOTAL SERVICES PROVIDED PER CAPITA 2002, 2003 AND 2004

item.para: Notes to the Statistics
The statistics relate to services that were rendered on a âfee-for-serviceâ basis for which benefits were processed by the Health Insurance Commission in 2002, 2003 and 2004.

Since the statistics sought relate to âservices provided in â¦â the statistics were compiled from Medicare data by servicing provider postcode. Medicare statistics by electorate published on the Department of Health and Ageing web site were compiled from patient enrolment postcode data.

In compiling the statistics, where a postcode overlapped electoral boundaries, the data were allocated to electorate using a concordance file derived from population census data. This can result in some data being erroneously allocated to an adjoining electorate. Data have been excluded if postcodes were not present on the concordance file.

* Caution should be exercised in interpreting Medicare statistics by region of provider. Electorates containing major hospitals and health facilities and electorates that encompass major regional centres will have higher rates of service provision. This explains the relatively high per capita rate of services in Jagajaga.

Services per capita statistics were compiled using ABS population estimates at 30 June of the respective years. Since ABS population estimates by electorate are not yet available for 2004, the per capita estimates for 2004 were based on population estimates for 2003.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 1 December 2004:

item.para: How many individuals held a Safety Net Concession Card during (a) 2003, and (b) 2004 in (i) Western Australia, and (ii) the electoral division of Brand.

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: (i) and (ii) and (b) (i) and (ii) The total number of individuals who held a Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) Safety Net Concession card*, in Western Australia and the electoral division of Brand during 2003 and 2004 is as follows:

*Individuals who hold a PBS Safety Net Concession card are general patients (ie non-concession card holders) who have reached their safety net threshold and are now eligible to obtain their prescriptions at the concessional co-payment amount ($4.60) for the remainder of the calendar year.

Please note: This data does not include individuals or families who have reached the PBS Safety Net threshold who have not applied to the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) for a PBS Safety Net Card (PBS Safety Net Concession Card or PBS Safety Net Entitlement Card).

This data does not include individuals who hold a PBS Safety Net Entitlement card. These are concession card holders who have reached their safety net threshold and are now eligible to obtain their prescriptions for free for the remainder of the calendar year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 7 March 2005:

item.para: In respect of the Central Queensland University campus in Fiji, how many (a) undergraduates have sought student visa entry to Australia, (b) applicants for student visas have been rejected, (c) of those admitted to Australia, have had their visas cancelled for not abiding by visa requirements, and (d) of those admitted, are currently involved in DIMIA determinant processes relating to (i) the cancellation of visa and (ii) attempts to migrate permanently through Australian qualifications.
How many successful applicants for student visas with some Fiji campus studies have subsequently gained permanent residence in Australia.

talker.name: Cobb, John, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr John Cobb

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairsâ (DIMIAâs) post in Suva has reported that there have only been 2 applications at post by Chinese citizens for student visas in the current 2004-05 program year to end February, one of whom was a Central Queensland University (CQU) student. During the 2003-04 program year, 161 student visa applications from PRC citizens were lodged at the Suva post. Of these, 121 or 75 per cent were for study in the Higher Education Sector (subclass 573). The majority of these applications would have been from students at the Fiji campus of CQU seeking to transfer their studies to an Australian campus of CQU.

item.label: (b)
item.para: During the 2003-04 program year, there were a total of 8 applications refused by the Suva post for PRC nationals in the Higher Education Sector. The majority of these would have been from students who were studying or had studied at the Fiji campus of CQU.

item.label: (c)
item.para: In the 2003-04 program year, a total of 79 cancellations were reported against all students studying at a CQU campus in Australia (38 at the Sydney campus and 41 at the Melbourne campus) relating to students not attending classes or not meeting the academic course requirements.

To verify the exact numbers of CQU students who had their visa cancelled and had previously studied at the CQU campus in Fiji, would be a very resource intensive task as this information cannot be extracted directly from DIMIA systems.

(d)Â Â (i) For resource reasons, DIMIA is unable to verify the numbers currently involved in the determination process relating to visa cancellation, who previously studied at the CQU campus in Fiji. We anticipate that this number would be minimal, if any.

DIMIA is able to confirm that during the 2003-04 program year, the total number of Non-Compliance Notices (NCNs) issued to all students who were studying at a CQU campus in Australia was 1,020 (278 for students studying at the Melbourne campus and 742 for the Sydney campus). This figure relates to both NCNs issued for non-attendance at classes and poor academic performance and also administrative notices issued for reasons such as the student changing provider. The vast majority of these NCNs were related to administrative notices and would therefore not result in a cancellation.

item.label: (d) (i)
item.para: For resource reasons, DIMIA is unable to verify the numbers currently involved in the determination process relating to visa cancellation, who previously studied at the CQU campus in Fiji. We anticipate that this number would be minimal, if any.

DIMIA is able to confirm that during the 2003-04 program year, the total number of Non-Compliance Notices (NCNs) issued to all students who were studying at a CQU campus in Australia was 1,020 (278 for students studying at the Melbourne campus and 742 for the Sydney campus). This figure relates to both NCNs issued for non-attendance at classes and poor academic performance and also administrative notices issued for reasons such as the student changing provider. The vast majority of these NCNs were related to administrative notices and would therefore not result in a cancellation.

item.label: (ii)
item.para: DIMIA is unable to obtain data on how many former CQU Fiji students, who have since come to Australia, have applied for permanent residency based on Australian qualifications.

As at 31 March 2005 and based on data from the last three program years, 6 Chinese students who applied at DIMIAâs Suva post, had applied for permanent migration by way of a spouse or relative. Of these, 3 have been granted and 3 are currently in the determination process. There were no visas granted for permanent migration based on Australian qualifications.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 14Â MarchÂ 2005:

item.para: Has the Defence Department been involved in any studies concerning the possible impact of sonar on whales and dolphins; if so, what are the details.
Has the Defence Department been monitoring studies concerning the possible impact of sonar on whales and dolphins.

Is the Minister aware of (a) any evidence or reports linking whale and/or dolphin beaching with sonar use, (b) reports of the stranding of about eighty dolphins in Florida, USA earlier this year following use of mid-frequency and high-frequency sonar by the USS Philadelphia in the area of the stranding, (c) reports of thirty five whales being stranded off the Outer Banks of North Carolina in the last two months which coincided with US Navy sonar exercises in the area, and (d) a report by the International Whaling Commission in 2004 which supported a link between sonar use and whale deaths.
What procedures are in place with the RAN for the use of sonar in circumstances that may cause injury to marine mammals.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: No. While Defence has contributed in excess of $1 million to marine mammal research in Australia over the past five years, including ecology population, distribution and abundance studies, Defence has not conducted any studies that have knowingly exposed whales or dolphins to sonar. This work has guided the development of the management plans that have been implemented by the Royal Australian Navy to ensure activities involving the use of active sonar do not impact on marine mammals.
Yes.
(3)Â Â (a) to (d) Yes.

item.label: (3) (a)
item.para: to (d) Yes.

The Royal Australian Navy does not operate its equipment in a way that is likely to cause injury to marine mammals or harm the marine environment. The Environmental Management Plan for Australian Maritime Exercise Areas prescribes mitigation procedures to minimise the likelihood of adverse impacts on marine mammals and the marine environment. Strict protocols apply to the operation of sonar to ensure that marine mammals are not inadvertently exposed to high levels of acoustic energy that might affect their health or interfere with behavioral characteristics that are important to their survival. The controls in place are among the most stringent employed by any Navy in the world.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, in writing, on 10Â MayÂ 2005:
