talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

item.para: How many Australian Federal Police Officers were deployed outside Australia on 1 March 2005.
In which countries were the officers deployed and how many were deployed in each country.
For what periods of time were the officers deployed in each country.
How many Australian Federal Police Officers were there at 1 March 2005.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: As at 1 March 2005, 410 AFP officers were deployed overseas.Â A further 79 State police officers attached to the AFP International Deployment Group (IDG) were deployed overseas.
The locations of the 410 AFP officers deployed overseas are shown in the following table.
The locations of the 79 State police deployed overseas are shown in the following table.

The period of a deployment is dependant on the operational reasons for the deployment.Â Some deployments are short term for the purpose of establishing and building relationships pertinent to AFP operational issues.Â Deployments such as those to the International Network offices are generally for a period of two years and can be extended for a year based on performance and agreement with the posted AFP officer.Â The IDG deployments vary depending on operational planning, the location, the nature of the deployment and officer preferences.
As at 1 March 2005, the AFP employed 4906 personnel with an additional 85 State police officers attached.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 10Â May 2005:

quote.para: What are the (a) general orders and (b) naval orders applicable to naval officers boarding suspect illegal entry vessels.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.label: (a)
item.para: There are no âgeneral ordersâ.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The naval orders applicable to naval officers boarding suspect illegal entry vessels are contained in Australian Fleet Tactical Publication 1 â Maritime Command Orders. These orders are the personal orders of the Maritime Commander Australia and provide policy guidance to Maritime Command units. Operation Relex Rules of Engagement and the Operation Relex II Operation Order 01/04 are applicable to boarding suspected illegal entry vessels. Other orders applicable to naval officers are contained in standard Australian Defence Force operational publications. All these documents are classified and are not available for public release.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 10Â May 2005:

item.para: Has the Ministerâs department developed a boarding guide or manual to guide officers in respect of suspect illegal entry vessels; if so, what procedures and processes are set out in that guide or manual.
To whom is the guide or manual provided.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following information to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: Defence publication Australian Book of Reference 1920 (The Royal Australian Navy Manual of Military Training) provides guidance for generic boarding operations, and Operation Relex II Operation Order 01/04 provides specific guidance to officers in respect to boarding suspect illegal entry vessels.
These documents are classified and are not available for public release.

The manual and instructions detailed above are available to all personnel who are directly involved in either training for, or conducting related boarding operations for suspect illegal entry vessels.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 10Â May 2005:

item.para: How many naval vessels were assigned at 1 April 2005 to patrol Australiaâs northern waters against suspect illegal foreign vessels.
How many patrols are made (a) each month and (b) each year by naval vessels in Australiaâs northern waters.
From which ports do the patrols originate.
What is the area covered by each patrol.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: On 1 April 2005, there were four dedicated Fremantle Class Patrol Boats and one Major Fleet Unit assigned for duties against suspected illegal foreign vessels. One further patrol boat was enroute to a handover position. Five additional naval vessels were assigned to the Coastwatch led âOperation Clearwaterâ focus period in the Gulf of Carpenteria.

(2)Â Â (a) and (b) The force assignment of four Fremantle Class Patrol Boats and one Major Fleet Unit to conduct patrols is constant, at all times, under current Government of Australia requirements. The number of patrols conducted varies each month and year, as patrols are based on a constant rotation of available assets.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: and (b) The force assignment of four Fremantle Class Patrol Boats and one Major Fleet Unit to conduct patrols is constant, at all times, under current Government of Australia requirements. The number of patrols conducted varies each month and year, as patrols are based on a constant rotation of available assets.
Patrols originate from Cairns, Darwin, Christmas Island, Sydney and Perth.

The areas covered by the patrols vary depending on the threat, and the number and location of fishing vessels. Warships assigned for fisheries patrols respond to sightings from Coastwatch surveillance aircraft and assessment of response priorities by the Director General Coastwatch. The specific locations of assets assigned for suspect illegal entry vessel response are classified.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

item.para: Can the Minister confirm that Codex Alimentarius is considering the adoption of new guidelines for Vitamin and Mineral Supplements at its meeting in July 2005 and that the Australian submission on the proposed guidelines includes the statement that Australia will not be bound by the guidelines.
Will the Minister explain Australiaâs position on the guidelines being considered by Codex.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: I can confirm that the Codex Alimentarius Commission will be considering the adoption of the draft Guidelines for Vitamin and Mineral Food Supplements at its meeting in Rome in July 2005.

I can also confirm that Australiaâs position at the upcoming commission meeting states that it would not be bound by these guidelines. However this statement is subject to a critical provision, which limits the application of the guidelines to countries that regulate vitamin and mineral supplements as foods, being retained.

Australia regulates vitamin and mineral supplements as complementary medicine. As such, they are outside the scope of the currently drafted guidelines. Therefore, Australiaâs system of regulation of vitamin and mineral supplements as complementary medicines is not expected to be affected, nor would Australia be expected to be vulnerable to challenge under the relevant agreements of the World Trade Organization.

Australia played an active role in deliberations on the draft guidelines. In addition to supporting the aforementioned exception, Australia strongly supported a scientific risk-based approach to establishing maximum limits for vitamin and mineral food supplements. The approach to setting maximum limits had been strongly debated by the delegations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 11Â MayÂ 2005:

item.para: Further to the answer to question No. 218 (Hansard, 9 February 2005, page 112), what regulations, guidelines or other written directions govern the conduct of Resistance to Interrogation (RTI) exercises conducted by the Australian Defence Force.
What information do participants in RTI training receive about what they can expect during RTI exercises so as to ensure that there is fully informed consent to the training on their part.
Are RTI participants advised of their right to (a) terminate their participation in the exercise and (b) register any complaint about their treatment.
Who is responsible for the overall conduct of RTI exercises.
Aside from RTI interrogators and participants, who else is involved in RTI exercises (eg who is responsible for the detention of participants).
Who supervises RTI exercises in the field, including in relation to health and safety issues, and what is the minimum rank of a supervisor.
What arrangements are in place to ensure that an RTI exercise does not involve physical or sexual assault or other harm to any participants.
In respect of the Ministerâs advice concerning the practice of making RTI participants wear blacked ski goggles or airline sleeping masks, for how long may a RTI participant be vision deprived.

In respect of the Ministerâs advice concerning the practice of stripping participants naked during âadvanced practical trainingâ, for how long have RTI participants been left naked and what is the maximum permissible time that they may be deprived of clothing.

In respect of the Ministerâs advice that there is no physical contact between RTI interrogators and participants (except to lead a participant for safety reasons), is there physical contact between RTI participants and other persons involved in RTI exercises (eg Military Police or other persons responsible for the custody of RTI participants).

In respect of the Ministerâs advice concerning sleep deprivation, (a) what is the maximum time an RTI participant has been deprived of sleep, (b) what is the maximum permitted period of sleep deprivation, and (c) what means are employed to deprive RTI participants of sleep.

In respect of the Ministerâs advice concerning threats of physical and/or sexual abuse as a psychological ploy, what forms of physical or sexual abuse may be threatened by RTI interrogators and are any types of threat not permitted.
Can the Minister confirm that guard dogs have been used to intimidate and harass RTI participants: if so, are guard dogs employed in the presence of naked RTI participants.
Since March 1996, have any persons sustained injuries as a consequence of their participation in RTI exercises; if so, how many persons were injured and what were the injuries involved.

Since March 1996, have any RTI participants made any complaints as a consequence of their treatment by interrogators or any other persons involved in such exercises; if so, what was the nature of each complaint, what investigations were undertaken, and what was the outcome in each case.
What records are maintained concerning the treatment of individual participants in RTI exercises.
What records are maintained on the techniques employed by RTI interrogators in relation to individual participants.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: The regulations, guidelines or other written directions governing the conduct of Resistance to Interrogation (RTI) exercises conducted by the Australian Defence Force include:

Defence Instruction (General) Operations 39-1 Defence Combat Survival Policy (due to be re-released in a revised version re-titled Defence Instruction (General) Operations 39-1 Defence Conduct After Capture Policy) provides policy guidance for the conduct of all RTI training â both theory and practical.

Land Warfare Publication Intelligence 2-1-3 Resistance to Interrogation Training (2001) provides specific guidance to RTI trainers in terms of control/oversight mechanisms, permitted interrogation techniques and ploys, and the procedures to be employed within the simulated enemy interrogation centre. Land Warfare Publication Intelligence 2-1-3 will be re-written in 2006 to ensure that it aligns with the release of the new version of Defence Instruction (General) Operations 39-1 Defence Conduct After Capture Policy.
Prior to the commencement of any practical RTI activity, the Exercise Director gives all RTI trainers, guards and supporting staff detailed orders for the conduct of the activity.
Australian Defence Force members remain subject to legal considerations arising from the Crimes Act 1914, the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 and the Geneva Conventions.
All participants are fully briefed.
(3)Â Â (a) Yes. (b) Yes.

item.label: (3) (a)
item.para: Yes. (b) Yes.
Commander Training Command â Army has responsibilities to the Chief of the Defence Force (through the Chief of Army) for the overall conduct of RTI training.
Aside from RTI interrogators and trainees, an RTI exercise includes:
exercise conducting staff to oversee the safe and effective conduct of the RTI exercise;
medical and psychological personnel to monitor the well being of the trainees;
a Neutral Umpire to provide independent oversight of the conduct of the RTI training;

exercise support staff, including guards. At all times the Guard Force, and all other support staff, such as handlers for military working dogs, work to the direction and oversight of the Exercise Director and Conducting Officer; and
exercise logistic support staff, such as cooks or drivers.

For practical RTI training, the Commandant Defence Intelligence Training Centre acts as the Exercise Director to provide the necessary Conducting Authority oversight. In addition to the Exercise Director, a Conducting Officer of the minimum rank of Major (Equivalent) is appointed in writing to supervise RTI exercises in the field. Medical Officers, psychological personnel and a Neutral Umpire support the Conducting Officer in relation to health and safety issues.

Prior to a practical RTI exercise, the Conducting Officer provides a brief to all involved in the exercise, reminding them that physical or sexual assault, or other harm is absolutely not permitted. Supervision arrangements, such as the Neutral Umpire, ensure that no incident of physical or sexual assault, or other harm can occur during RTI exercise.

A RTI participant is vision deprived for the duration of a RTI practical activity, with the exception of simulated enemy interrogation sessions or when consulting with a Medical Officer, psychological personnel or the Neutral Umpire.

Trainees may be requested to strip naked for the purpose of searching. Nudity only occurs in advanced practical RTI training. Participants in basic practical training are only stripped to their underwear. In no circumstances are RTI trainees kept naked for a period longer than three hours in aggregate during the RTI exercise.
Physical contact by guards is only permitted during searching, as part of an exercise ploy or for safety reasons, such as guiding a trainee who is blindfolded.
In respect of sleep deprivation:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Defence is not able to devote the considerable time and resources required to search individual service records to determine this information. Medical Officers closely supervise sleep deprivation of a trainee during practical RTI training.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Trainees receive a limited amount of sleep during an RTI exercise under medical supervision.

item.label: (c)
item.para: Trainees stand and move at least every 20 minutes.

The Conducting Officer, in consultation with the Medical Officer and Neutral Umpire, must approve any specific ploy concerning threats of physical and/or sexual abuse proposed by a simulated enemy interrogator.

When approved by the Exercise Director, working military dogs that are muzzled and short-leashed may be used during advanced RTI training, in the presence of RTI trainees (including naked trainees), in order to create realism.

Defence is not able to devote the considerable time and resources required to search individual service records to determine this information. A trainee may speak to a Medical Officer or Neutral Umpire at any time during a practical RTI exercise.

Defence is not able to devote the considerable time and resources required to search individual service records to determine this information. During the post activity debrief process participants are reminded that they have an opportunity to register any complaint about their treatment with the Conducting Officer, the Medical Officer or the supporting psychologists.
A file is created for each trainee in RTI exercises. All details relevant to a traineeâs RTI training experience is recorded in the traineeâs file
A traineeâs file contains detail on the techniques employed by simulated enemy interrogators in relation to individual RTI trainees.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 12 May 2005:

item.para: Is the Ministerâs department aware of the claim made in March by Rwandaâs Deputy Attorney-General, Mr Martin Ngoga, that as many as 300 Rwandans implicated in the genocide against Tutsis have been accepted in Australia and other nations; if so, has the validity of this claim been investigated; if not, will the validity of this claim now be investigated.
How many applications for migration made by Rwandans were (a) accepted and (b) rejected in (i) 1996, (ii) 1997, (iii) 1998, (iv) 1999, and (v) 2000.
What action is taken to minimise the possibility of perpetrators of major human rights abuses migrating to Australia.

talker.name: Cobb, John, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr John Cobb

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: My Department is aware of the claim made by Deputy Attorney-General, Mr Martin Ngoga, in March 2004. It is not aware of any perpetrators of the 1994 genocide in Rwanda living in Australia. My Department would welcome any information from the Rwandan Government that could assist it to identify persons in Australia who have committed war crimes or human rights abuses
Rwandan Visa Applicants 1996 to 2004

Note: Apparent discrepancies between number of applicants and number of decisions are due to time lags in processing of applications. An applicant may apply in one program year and be granted or refused in a subsequent program year.

All applicants for entry to Australia must meet character requirements. These include that they have not been involved in human rights abuses or war crimes. In order to ensure that persons entering Australia are of good character, my Department gathers information on countries where war crimes or crimes against humanity have taken place and uses this information to develop screening tools for applicants from those countries. Rwandans resettled under the refugee program would have also been screened by UNHCR in relation to their need and background. Further, there are over 1000 names of Rwandans who may have taken part in human rights abuses held in departmental databases. These have been sourced from the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, other countries and open source information. Any allegation about the involvement of a non-citizen in war crimes or human rights abuse is investigated by my Department. If substantiated, action can be taken to cancel any current visa and refuse further visas.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 30 May 2005:

item.para: Have there been any changes to the Medicare schedule that have impacted on the availability to women of a free mammogram examination; if so, what are the details.
What services are available to enable women to receive free mammogram examinations and are those services either limited or targeted to women in particular age groups.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: There have been no recent changes to the Medicare Benefits Schedule relating to mammographic examination of the breast.

Diagnostic mammography is for women who have clinical breast symptoms that require investigation. Diagnostic mammograms are usually taken in conjunction with clinical assessment. These services are not designed to recruit and screen large numbers of women who are likely to benefit from regular screening mammography. The current scheduled fee to have a diagnostic mammogram, under the Medicare Benefits Schedule, is $89.50. Private practices may charge above this fee.
Women without symptoms or a previous history or family history of breast cancer are not entitled to a Medicare rebate and would have to pay the full cost of the mammogram.

Free screening mammographic examinations are available to eligible Australian women every two years through BreastScreen Australia, a joint initiative of state and territory governments and the Australian Government funded through the Public Health Outcome Funding Agreements. States and territories have primary responsibility for the implementation of the program at their local level. The Australian Government provides overall coordination of policy formulation, national data collection, quality control, monitoring and evaluation.

BreastScreen Australia is the national mammographic screening program. It provides free screening mammograms at two-yearly intervals for women aged 50â69 with the aim of reducing deaths from breast cancer in this target group, through early detection of the disease. The target age group for screening is women aged 50-69 years, but women aged 40-49 years and over 70 years are also eligible to attend, however women in these age groups are not actively recruited into the program.

International research has shown that breast cancer screening of women aged 50-69 years is an effective way to reduce the number of women who die from breast cancer. Women aged 70 years and over are advised to discuss the requirement for ongoing screening with their general practitioner to assist them in making an informed decision about whether or not to continue having screening mammograms.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 30 May 2005:

item.para: What sum has been allocated to the Australian Broadcasting Corporationâs Radio National for (a) 2003-2004, (b) 2004-2005, and (c) 2005-2006.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: to (c) The Government provides an overall level of funding for the ABC, but has no power to direct the allocation of funds to individual networks such as Radio National. Parliament has guaranteed this independence to ensure that what is broadcast is free of political interference. Management of the ABCâs internal budget is the responsibility of the ABC Board and Executive.
The ABC has advised that Radio Nationalâs budget allocations for the years requested are as follows:
2005/06 $16,443,696 (indicative as budgets have not yet been allocated)
The ABC has advised that there are no plans to vary that allocation in future.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 31 May 2005:

quote.para: In respect of the $54,353 contract entered into by his department in 2004-2005 with ALT Beatty Consulting to âdevelop a national quality assurance framework and monitoring systemâ, (a) what specific tasks were carried out by ALT Beatty Consulting under the contract, (b) with which groups did ALT Beatty Consulting consult as part of the project, and (c) why was it considered necessary to engage a consultant rather than his department carrying out the work.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: ALT Beatty Consulting was engaged to develop a National Quality Assurance Framework and Monitoring System (the Framework) for the new joint-funded Transition Care Program which was announced as part of the Investing in Australiaâs Aged Care: More Places, Better Care package of the 2004-05 federal Budget. The contract required the consultant to develop the Framework through identifying relevant existing legislation and frameworks and mapping these to a new transition care quality assurance framework. The Framework was to cover, but not be limited to, issues such as building quality, quality of care, appropriate external complaints mechanisms, compliance and management systems. The consultant was also required to provide advice on a longer term approach for quality assurance and monitoring in the Transition Care Program.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Representatives from each state and territory government health department and the Department of Health and Ageing; several aged care providers and two clinicians from the Clinical Reference Group of the Australian Health Minstersâ Advisory Councilâs Care of Older Australians Working Group.

item.label: (c)
item.para: The Australian Government has collaborated with all states and territories through a Transition Care Task Group (TCTG) in developing the key parameters of the Transition Care Program, including quality issues. The TCTG agreed on 10 November 2004 to engage an independent consultant with the necessary expertise to research and draft a quality assurance framework based on existing state, territory and Commonwealth legislation and regulations. It was considered necessary to engage a consultant in order to (a) secure the necessary independent expertise for the task; and (b) complete the work in a timeframe consistent with the Australian Governmentâs commitment to allocate transition care places by 30 June 2005.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 31 May 2005:

item.para: Has he read the article âBudget pain for bone diseaseâ in The Sunday Telegraph on 15 May 2005 which reported that âhundreds of thousands of Australians suffering crippling bone disease could be âhiddenâ victims of the Budgetâ and that âin a little-noticed move, Treasurer Peter Costello introduced tough cost-cutting measures that will make it more expensive for people to access calcium supplements aimed at warding off osteoporosisâ.
Can he confirm that the Government will remove calcium tablets from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) to save $35.9 million over four years; if not, why not.

Can he confirm that concession card holders (a) currently pay $4.60 per prescription and (b) will be required to pay at least $8.40 more, or up to $13 for a bottle of calcium tablets; if not, why not.

Is he aware that calcium tablets are a basic preventive measure that helps hundreds of thousands of Australians; including (a) elderly people (b) cancer patients (c) kidney transplant patients and (d) those using corticosteroids for asthma, rheumatoid arthritis and other autoimmune diseases, treat and avoid osteoporosis; if not, why not.

Can he confirm that osteoporosis costs Australia (a) $1.9 billion per annum directly in health costs and (b) $5.6 billion in indirect costs; if so, can he explain how removing calcium tablets from the PBS will not be unfair and counter-productive.

Will he act to prevent this additional cost being imposed on older Australians and on those at severe risk of osteoporosis because of cancer treatment or a kidney transplant; if so, when, if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs questions is as follows:

item.para: Yes.

Yes, the delisting of calcium tablets from the PBS was one of the Budget measures and is expected to save around $36 million over four years. The National Health Act (1953) requires that the advice of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) is obtained before action is taken to delist a PBS medicine. The PBAC is an independent, expert advisory body whose members include medical practitioners, health scientists, other health professionals and a consumer representative. The advice must be tabled in both houses of the Parliament.

(3)Â Â (a) and (b) Yes, concession card holders currently pay $4.60 for PBS prescriptions. Calcium tablets are relatively inexpensive and available over the counter at most pharmacies for around $13 to $15 for two months supply.

(4)Â Â (a) to (d) Yes. I am aware that many people take calcium tablets for a variety of reasons and conditions. The PBS includes a wide variety of medicines for many conditions, but it is not possible and it is not intended that the PBS cover every useful treatment.

(5)Â Â (a) and (b) Access Economics has estimated the direct cost of osteoporosis to be $1.9 billion per annum, and the indirect cost to be $5.6 billion per annum, based on a costing for 2000-01 (Access Economics 2001. The Burden of Brittle Bones: Costing Osteoporosis in Australia.)

Cost estimations vary widely with the large variety of methodologies used and there is no generally accepted costing methodology. The Australian Government uses the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare as its statistical data source, including for costing estimates. For an indicative comparison, the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare estimates that the direct cost of osteoporosis in 2000-01 was $221 million (Australian Institute of Health and Welfare (2004), Health system expenditure on disease and injury in Australia, 2000-01, AIHW Cat no HWE 26, AIHW: Canberra http/www.aihw.gov.au). The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare does not provide estimates of indirect costs.

Using the methodology adopted by the AIHW, pharmaceuticals accounted for the greatest proportion of the expenditure for osteoporosis, followed by expenditure on aged care homes and hospital services in 2000â01.

Subsidies for inexpensive medicines, such as calcium tablets, make only a small difference in affordability for individuals. It is preferable that PBS dollars are directed to those medicines that would otherwise be difficult for individuals to afford. The measure supports PBS affordability by reducing the cost to government of subsidised medicines and improving value for money from the scheme.

Medicines listed on the PBS for use in the treatment of osteoporosis with a related fracture will continue to be subsidised. These medicines need to be prescribed by a doctor and, at between $50 - $60 for one monthâs treatment, are much more expensive than calcium tablets. PBS subsidies for these other drugs for osteoporosis cost over $130 million per year.

(4)Â Â (a) to (d) Yes. I am aware that many people take calcium tablets for a variety of reasons and conditions. The PBS includes a wide variety of medicines for many conditions, but it is not possible and it is not intended that the PBS cover every useful treatment.

(5)Â Â (a) and (b) Access Economics has estimated the direct cost of osteoporosis to be $1.9 billion per annum, and the indirect cost to be $5.6 billion per annum, based on a costing for 2000-01 (Access Economics 2001. The Burden of Brittle Bones: Costing Osteoporosis in Australia.)

No, this issue would first need to be considered by the PBAC.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 1 June 2005:

quote.para: Further to the answer to question No. 602, can the Minister explain how the Government will protect the public interest and maintain a diverse and vibrant media sector while pursuing its objective to amend Australiaâs cross-media ownership laws.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

quote.para: I have nothing further to add to the information provided previously.
As noted in my answer to question No. 602, the Government is currently considering its approach to media ownership reform.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 2 June 2005:

item.para: Is the Minister aware of a blood test called the âBeryllium Lymphocyte Proliferation testâ.
Is this test available in Australia; if not, why not and when will it become available.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: I am aware of the Beryllium Lymphocyte Proliferation Test (BeLPT), and its place in the diagnosis of chronic beryllium disease in conjunction with a clinical history and examination, diagnostic imaging, respiratory function testing and biopsy if required.

There are no laboratories currently performing the test. This is due to low demand and resulting issues with validation and quality assurance. I understand there is potential for a university laboratory in Newcastle to commence testing in the near future.
Should the test be performed, a Medicare benefit for the BeLPT would be payable against item 71127 in the Pathology Services Table.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on 14 June 2005:

item.para: In respect of the $34.6 million program over four years to promote values in public education, how many values education forums have been held in Australian public schools.
What costs were incurred to hold the forums.
Has a performance review been conducted on the success or otherwise of these forums.
What curriculum and assessment resources for teaching on values have been developed.
Which Champion schools have been identified and how have their best practice approaches been pub-licised.
What other national activities, including partnership projects with parents, teachers, school principals and teachers, have been conducted as part of the Values in Public Education program.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr Nelson

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: None to date. Negotiations to achieve cross-sectoral proposals in each State and Territory took up to six months to complete. Cross sectoral contracts with all States and Territories are now in place.
The contracts with education authorities for the forums include the following payment schedule:
No.

Professional learning resources are being developed to assist teachers implement values education. The Values for Australian Schooling Kit 2005 will be distributed to all schools shortly. This kit will contain professional learning resources for teachers on developing values education in primary and secondary schools and a resource for schools to help them conduct their values education forums. These will also be available on the values education website (http://www.valueseducation.edu.au). The kit will also include a professional learning DVD and support materials. Additional resources for teachers are available on the website.
26 clusters of schools were selected to participate in the Values Education Good Practice Schools Project â Stage 1 in May 2005. These clusters include:

entry.para: Calwell High School (with Isabella Plains, Richardson, Theodore and Calwell Primary Schools)
Building Community Values Through Restorative Practices and Emotional Literacy
Lightning Ridge Central School (with Enngonia and Nyngan Public Schools, Goodooga Central School and Bourke High School)
Implementing values through a community focus group approach.
Merrylands High School (with Sherwood Grange, Merrylands East, Merrylands, Guildford West, Hilltop Road and Guildford Public Schools)
Values in Action: Our Community Counts!
Domremy College (with Bethlehem, Casimir Catholic, Holy Spirit and De La Salle Colleges)

St Peterâs Catholic College, Tuggerah Lakes (with Mercy College, St Phillip Neri, Our Lady of Good Counsel, St Ceciliaâs and St Martin de Porres Schools, and Our Lady of the Rosary, St Brendanâs, and St Bernardâs Primary Schools)
Teaching Australian Values in a Catholic Community
Airds High School (with Woodland Road, Bradbury, and John Warby Public Schools and Briar Road School)
âFive for Nineâ - Five Schools, Nine Values
Henbury School (with Stuart Park, Anula, Humpty Doo and Wanguri Primary Schools, Batchelor Area School, and Wallace Rockhole School)
Creating Safe and Supportive Learning Communities

Sacred Heart SchoolÂ (with St Francis Xavier, Murrupurtiyanuwu Catholic School, Xavier Community Education Centre, St Paulâs Primary, St Josephâs College, St Francis of Assisi school, St Maryâs Primary, Holy Family Primary, St Johnâs College
Values Education through a TRIBES process
Canterbury College (with St Hildaâs School and Marsden and Loganlea State High Schools)
Middle Schooling, Values and Values Education - Service-Learning: Making the Connections
Oxenford State School (with Upper Coomera State College, Bellevue Park State School and Southport State High School)
Townsville Central State School (with Magnetic Island, Garbutt, Oonoonba, Townsville West, Belgian Gardens and Railway Estate State Schools)
Heights College (with Bundaberg, Emerald, Mackay and Calvary Christian Colleges)
Chapel Hill State School (with Kenmore South, Fig Tree Pocket, Brookfield, Upper Brookfield, Mount Crosby State Schools, Kenmore State High School and The Glenleighden School)

item.para: Schools commenced their projects in May and will conclude them in May 2006. Information about the good practice approaches that these clusters of schools are implementing is available on the values education website at http://www.valueseducation.edu.au. The website will provide regular updates on the progress of these projects during the year.
A national forum and partnership projects with parent, teacher, school principal and teacher organisations have been conducted as part of the Values Education programme.

The 2005 Values Education National Forum was held in Canberra on 2 and 3 May. 130 delegates attended. The forum provided an opportunity for discussions about the implementation of the National Framework for Values Education in Australian and future directions for values education. The programme included workshops demonstrating good practice in values education, student voice and key note and international speakers.

The Australian Principals Associations Professional Development Council representing school principals has developed a page on their website devoted to values education, produced a series of electronic newsletters and engaged principals through an internet event.

The Australian Joint Council of Professional Teacher Associations representing teachers has held a national symposium to discuss values education and is conducting forums with teacher associations in each State and Territory.

The Australian Council of Deans of Education representing teacher educators is holding a series of meetings to inform teacher educators in each State and Territory about the latest developments in values education.

The Australian Council of State School Organisations (ACSSO) and the Australian Parents Council are producing values education leaflets for parents. ACSSO has a values education page on their website.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts and Sport, in writing, on 15 June 2005:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, in writing, on 21 June 2005:

item.para: Can he confirm that carers over age pension age and eligible to claim the Age Pension are not able to claim Carers Payment.

Can he confirm carers in receipt of (a) the Age Pension and Carers Allowance were entitled to the one off payment of $600; (b) carers in receipt of the Carers Payment were entitled to the one off payment of $1000; and (c) carers in receipt of both Carers Payment and Carers Allowance were entitled to a combined one off payment of $1600.

Is it the case that a discrepancy exists between a carer in receipt of the Age Pension and Carers Allowance rather than Carers Payment who would, if it were not for their entitlement to Age Pension, be entitled to receive Carers Payment, in that they are not eligible for the one off payment of $1000; if so, will he address the discrepancy by increasing the one-off payment for carers in receipt of the Age Pension to match the entitlement of the one-off payment paid to those in receipt of Carers Payment and, if he will not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: Carers over age pension age are able to claim either Age Pension or, if they meet the eligibility criteria, Carer Payment.
(2)Â Â (a)Â Â Yes, carers in receipt of Age Pension and Carer Allowance were entitled to a bonus payment of $600 as announced in the 2005-06 Budget;

item.label: (a)
item.para: Yes, carers in receipt of Age Pension and Carer Allowance were entitled to a bonus payment of $600 as announced in the 2005-06 Budget;

item.label: (b)
item.para: Yes, carers in receipt of Carer Payment were entitled to a one-off bonus payment of $1,000 as announced in the 2005-06 Budget;

item.label: (c)
item.para: Yes, carers in receipt of both Carer Payment and Carer Allowance were entitled to a combined one-off bonus payment of $1,600 as announced in the 2005-06 Budget.

Carers on Age Pension who receive Carer Allowance have received $600 for each care recipient. Carers over age pension age can qualify for Carer Payment by meeting the eligibility criteria including the need to provide constant care. The one-off bonus legislation passed by Parliament was specifically for Carer Payment and Carer Allowance recipients in recognition of their contribution in the role of carer to someone with a disability. The majority of the bonus payments were made in JuneÂ 2005.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 22 June 2005:

item.para: Which Minister is responsible for the strategic positioning and monitoring of Australiaâs Overseas Development Assistance (ODA)-eligible Other Government Department (OGD) expenditure.

Why does AusAID have responsibility for the collection of data relating to ODA-eligible OGD expenditure but no capacity to monitor or provide a strategic framework for which the expenditures can be integrated into a whole-of-government approach.
Can he explain why it is appropriate to have a significant sum of ODA in the form of OGD expenditure without it being monitored and reviewed by a single Minister and agency.
Can he explain why it is appropriate to have a significant sum of ODA in the form of OGD expenditure outside the direction of the Minister for Foreign Affairs.
Will he review the existing arrangements applying to ODA-eligible OGD expenditure to give one Minister and agency responsibility for the expenditures, if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The Minister for Foreign Affairs is responsible for monitoring and reporting on Australiaâs levels of Official Development Assistance (ODA). This includes both AusAID and ODA eligible expenditure by other government departments. A range of inter-governmental coordination mechanisms are used to ensure a strong and coherent whole-of-government approach to the strategic positioning of development assistance. Australiaâs level of policy coherence on development issues and its innovative whole-of-government approach was commended by the Development Assistance Committee (DAC) of the OECD in its review of the Australian aid program in December 2004.

The DAC is the principal body through which the OECD addresses issues related to development cooperation, and is the key forum and review body for major bilateral donors. Official Development Assistance (ODA) is the primary quantitative measure used by the DAC to compare donor efforts. The DAC sets and provides guidance on ODA eligibility of government expenditures.

AusAID, as the Australian Governmentâs aid agency, is responsible, in cooperation with other Government departments, for reporting to the DAC on Australiaâs ODA. The Minister and AusAID drive and participate in a variety of inter-governmental coordination mechanisms. This ensures the aid program remains part of a broader, integrated whole-of-government approach to engaging with the region. However, the performance and expenditure of individual departments within the Governmentâs broader approach remain the responsibility of the relevant Ministers. This is the logical and most practical approach, given that ODA eligible expenditure constitutes only a part of the overall expenditures of other government departments.
The level of ODA in the form of OGD expenditure is monitored by a single Minister and agency, namely the Minister for Foreign Affairs and AusAID.

Development issues in our region are increasingly complex and require the engagement of not just one Australian Government department, but an integrated whole-of-government approach. While AusAID remains responsible for reporting on levels of ODA eligible expenditure related to these approaches, individual departments and Ministers remain responsible for delivery of their respective contributions. It is therefore appropriate that individual Ministers and departments remain responsible for their performance and expenditures.
See above.

No. The most appropriate approach to ODA-eligible OGD expenditure is that individual Ministers and departments remain responsible for their performance, within broader whole-of-government coordination mechanisms.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 22 June:

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The total value of Australiaâs Official Development Assistance (ODA) in 2003-04 was $1.973 billion. For 2004-05, the expected ODA outcome is estimated at $2.253 billion.
The total value of ODA-eligible Other Government Department Expenditure for 2003-04 was $275.1 million. For 2004-05, the expected outcome is estimated at $491.9 million.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: How many parents or caregivers of students in the electoral division of Holt (which includes the postcode areas 3156, 3177, 3802, 3803, 3804, 3805, 3806, 3975, 3976, 3977 and 3978) have received vouchers for tutorial assistance under the Pilot Tutorial Voucher Initiative since the commencement of the program.

Based on the pre and post-tuition assessment of students, what is the difference in the reading levels achieved by students who have participated in the program in the electoral division of Holt.
How many parents or caregivers in the electoral division of Holt who approached the broker to participate in the program were unable or unwilling to access suitable tuition.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr Nelson

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: In the electoral division of Holt (incorporating postcodes 3156, 3177, 3802, 3803, 3804, 3805, 3806, 3976, 3976, 3977 and 3978), twenty eight parents/caregivers of students who attend school in the electorate have applied for Tutorial Vouchers since the commencement of the Tutorial Voucher Initiative in Victoria on 2 March 2005.

Of the twenty eight parents of students in the electoral division of Holt, nineteen attend state schools, six attend non-government schools, and three are to be determined as they have not yet submitted all application forms.

Delivery of tutorial assistance to students in the electoral division of Holt is ongoing. At present, none of these students has finished the twelve tutorial sessions or completed the post-assessment. Accordingly, it is not possible to determine the difference in reading levels of these students at this time.

Of the twenty eight parents of students in the electoral division of Holt who applied to the broker, three have not participated in the pilot Initiative for the following reasons: two parents declined the tutor; and one declined as the parentâs availability did not match the availability of the tutor.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Small Business and Tourism, in writing, on 23Â JuneÂ 2005:

item.para: Is the Governmentâs 25% Entrepreneurs Tax Offset calculated on the basis of a businessâs turnover; if not, how is it calculated.
Do home-based businesses which sell products

item.label: (a)
item.para: pay higher input costs than home-based businesses that provide services,

item.label: (b)
item.para: carry the burden of input costs in their turnover, and

item.label: (c)
item.para: miss out on this tax discount because their turnover is too high; if not, why not.

Will the Government introduce amendments to the 25% Entrepreneurs Tax Offset to ensure homebased businesses which sell products and not services are able to benefit from this tax discount; if so, when; if not, why not.

talker.name: Bailey, Fran, MP
talker.role: Minister for Small Business and Tourism
talker.name: Fran Bailey

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: Taxation matters fall within the portfolio responsibility of Treasury Ministers.

The Entrepreneursâ Tax Offset will provide small businesses in the Simplified Tax System with a turnover of $50,000 or less a 25 per cent tax discount on the tax liability relating to their business income. The discount also applies to businesses with turnovers above $50,000 but tapers out at the rate of one per cent per $1,000 turnover, so that it ceases once turnover reaches $75,000.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics does not currently collect cost structures for home-based businesses. Therefore it is not possible to make a comparison between the cost structure of home-based service businesses and those that sell products.

As announced in the 2004 election, the discount is targeted at very small businesses. The Government has no plans to make amendments to the legislation for the entrepreneursâ tax discount at this point in time.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Youth Ambassador for Development Program

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Why was the funding for the Youth Ambassador program increased by $24.5 million?
What is the breakdown of the (a) existing funding to the Youth Ambassador program and (b) additional funding for the Youth Ambassador Program?

Does the 2005-2006 Budget still include funding for Australian Volunteers International, AESOP Business Volunteers, Interserve and PALMS Australia; if so, what is the breakdown of the funds each of these organisations received and the activities it was allocated for?
How many Youth Ambassadors were recruited in (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998, (d) 1999, (e) 2000, (f)Â 2001, (g) 2002, (h) 2003, (i) 2004, and (j) 2005?
To which countries are Youth Ambassadors sent?
How many Youth Ambassadors were sent to each country identified in part (5) in (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998, (d) 1999, (e) 2000, (f) 2001, (g) 2002, (h) 2003, (i) 2004, and (j) 2005?
Which country has received the (a) highest and (b) lowest number of Youth Ambassadors?
What is the formal process for selecting the countries which receive Youth Ambassadors?
What mechanisms are in place to determine the number of people that go to each country?
What educational or work qualifications do Youth Ambassadors need and what are the criteria for selecting Youth Ambassadors?
What is the job description?
Are Youth Ambassadors expected to adhere to Key Performance Indicators; if so, what are they; if not, why not?
Are Youth Ambassadors required to submit reports documenting their progress?
Are Youth Ambassadors obligated to provide a formal report upon returning to Australia?
Do former participants of the program have any involvement in recruiting new participants; if so, what role do they play?
What training do Youth Ambassadors undergo before starting their placement?
Do Youth Ambassadors have any obligations to the program after the completion of their placement?
Are there any out-of-pocket expenses for Youth Ambassadors during their training and placement; if so, what are they?
Is there a travel/living allowance provided to Youth Ambassadors; if so, what is it?
Who is charged with recruiting the Youth Ambassadors?
How are the recruiters chosen?

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The funding for the Australian Youth Ambassador for Development (AYAD) Program was increased by $24.5 million to allow for a significant increase in the number of placements offered annually to young Australians.Â Current targets are 230 Youth Ambassadors placed each year.Â By 2006, there will be around 400 young Australians sent overseas for development assignments under the program.

The annual allocation for the Australian Youth Ambassador for Development Program in FY 2004-05 was $7 million. (b)Â The breakdown of additional $24.5 million allocation for the following financial years is $3.5 million in 2005-06 and $7 million for each of the next three financial years.

Following the public tender for the delivery of Volunteer Services to the Australian Aid Program, three organisations have been contracted to provide volunteers: Australian Volunteers International (AVI), Australian Business Volunteers (ABV) and Austraining International Pty Ltd (AI).
Interserve did not submit an expression of interest.
PALMS Australia was unsuccessful in the technical assessment.

The amount each organisation is contracted for in 2005-2006 is AVI $8.75 million, ABV $2.6 million and AI $3.79 million.Â PALMS Australia will receive approximately $100,000 to finalise volunteers currently in the field.
Since inception in 1998, the number of Youth Ambassadors recruited is as follows:
Australian Youth Ambassadors are sent to the following countries:
The number of Youth Ambassadors sent to each country since inception is as follows:

item.label: (7) (a)
item.para: Vietnam received the highest number of Youth Ambassadors; and (b) Indonesia received the lowest number of Youth Ambassadors.

The Australian Youth Ambassadors for Development Program places Youth Ambassadors in countries in the Asia Pacific region.Â The formal process for selecting the countries which receive Youth Ambassadors involves consultation with AusAID Country Program areas and AusAID Posts in eligible countries.Â The selection of eligible countries is determined by Australian aid program geographic priorities and the security environment of individual countries in the Asia Pacific region.

The number of Youth Ambassador placements in each country is determined by demand for Youth Ambassadors from partner countries, aid program country strategies, Australian aid program priorities and the security environment in individual countries.
Educational, work qualifications and criteria for selecting Youth Ambassadors vary with each placement.Â This information is available on AusAID website: www.ausaid.gov.au/youtham
Each placement has a specific job description.Â A list of around 200 placements with job descriptions is available on the Program website: www.ayad.com.au

Yes.Â An initial work plan developed by the Host organisation and agreed by the Youth Ambassador describes objectives and the key tasks the Youth Ambassador will be expected to undertake.Â This Initial work plan also outlines performance indicators that are specific to each Youth Ambassador placement.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes. It is a requirement of the Australian Youth Ambassadors for Development Program that a returned Youth Ambassador is a member of the selection panel.

All Youth Ambassadors attend a comprehensive 5 days pre-departure training program before they leave Australia.Â This include cross-cultural training, security briefing, development issues briefing, insurance briefing and health and safety procedures briefing covering all aspects of living in a foreign environment.Â They are also provided with training on arrival in-country.Â This includes AusAID Post briefing, emergency and evacuation procedures and may include language training.
Yes. Youth Ambassadors are obliged to join the returned Youth Ambassadors alumni network and participate in promoting the Australian Youth Ambassadors Program.
No.

Yes. The AYAD Program provides funds to cover all expenses incurred by the Youth Ambassadors during the term of their placement.Â Australian Partner Organisations sometimes contribute to the living and accommodation allowance but this is not mandatory.
Allowances are as follows:
Establishment Allowance: All Youth Ambassadors receive a $600 establishment allowance to cover expenses related to visa, resources, excess baggage, costs of setting up accommodation in-country, etc.
Living/Accommodation Allowance: Youth Ambassadors receive monthly living and accommodation allowances.Â Rate of monthly allowance by country is as follows:
Papua New Guinea 1 is placements in Port Moresby
Papua New Guinea 2 is any placement other than Post Moresby

Assignment Support Allowance:Â All Youth Ambassadors are provided with $350 at the commencement of their assignment (this is in addition to the Establishment Allowance). This allowance is for the purchase of books, equipment, and other relevant items to support the assignment. If the assignment exceeds 6 months in duration then an additional amount of $350 will be available to support the assignment.

Resettlement Allowance:Â A resettlement allowance ofÂ $600 is provided to all Youth Ambassadors to assist with costs associated with settling back into Australia. This allowance is paid to the Youth Ambassadors after successful completion of their placement and submission of the end of assignment evaluation report.
Austraining International Pty Ltd, the Australian managing contractor, is responsible for the selection and recruitment of Youth Ambassadors.
Austraining International Pty Ltd, the Australian managing contractor was selected through a competitive tender process.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

How does he account for the $3.3 million discrepancy between the table and explanation and to what has the $3.3 million been allocated.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The funding for Other International Programs as listed on page 73 of the Ministerâs Statement on Australiaâs Overseas Aid Program 2005-06 is estimated at $39.2 million
Of this total, an estimated $36 million has been allocated to International Health Programs as listed on page 55 of the Ministerâs Statement.

The remaining $3.2 million includes estimated contributions to the Global Conservation Trust ($2 million), the Consultative Group to Assist the Poor ($1 million), and the International Tropical Timber Organisation ($0.2 million).

Organisations receiving funding under Other International Programs include the three organisations listed above, together with estimated funding to the following organisations: the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria ($20 million); the World Health Organisation ($7 million); UNAIDS ($4 million); and other international health programs and activities ($5 million).Â The latter includes funding for the International Planned Parenthood Federation, together with funding to address emerging pandemics and other health needs that may emerge during 2005-06.
As above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: What sum from the aid budget will be allocated to programs which are part of the Regional Assistance Mission to Solomon Islands.
How many new initiatives have been started this year and what sum will each initiative receive.
Have any initiatives received less funding or been eliminated; if so, why.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: Aid budget allocations to RAMSIÂ [2003-2009]
AusAID RAMSI estimated expenditure by program 2004/05

RAMSI program initiatives in 2004/05 focus on implementing reforms in the three key pillars of economic governance, machinery of government and law and justice. Some of the key new projects in 2004/05 include assistance to accountability institutions, a partnership with the Australian Electoral Commission to strengthen the Solomon Islands electoral system, phase 2 of the Budget Stabilisation Program (known as the Financial Management Strengthening Program), the parliamentary support project and assistance to the high profile High Court trials.

Final expenditure figures for 2004/05 are not yet available, however it is anticipated that actual expenditure will vary from estimated expenditure (above) given significant increased demands on support to the Solomon Islands justice system, in particular the High Court trials. The needs of the justice sector have been able to be met from the Machinery of Government program, an initiative which is still in an early phase.
As above

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Which countries receive assistance under the Australian Partnerships with African Communities program.
What sum did each country receive under the program in (a) 2002, (b) 2003 (c) 2004, and (d) 2005.
Were any countries taken on or off the list in (a) 2002, (b) 2003 (c) 2004, and (d) 2005; if so, which ones and why.
What are the criteria for countries to be included in the program.
Was Eritrea ever included in the program: if so, when.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The following seven countries receive assistance under the Australian Partnerships with African Communities program:
South Africa
Mozambique
Malawi
Zambia
Zimbabwe
Kenya
Uganda
The Australian Partnerships with African Communities (APAC) program commenced on 1 July 2004. APAC is implemented on a financial year basis.

item.label: (a)
item.para: 2002. Nil. The APAC program did not exist in 2002.

item.label: (b)
item.para: 2003. Nil. The APAC program did not exist in 2003.

item.label: (c)
item.para: 2004. Total design funds (not expended on a country basis) for the period January to April 2004 was $811,184.

item.label: (d)
item.para: In the financial year 2004/05 the program expended $9,242,891 as follows:
No countries were taken on or off the list in 2002, 2003, 2004 and 2005.

The country criteria used was that the country must be one of the ten target countries of Australiaâs Development Co-operation with Africa Framework for 2003-2007. The ten target countries are in southern and eastern Africa and include South Africa, Lesotho, Swaziland, Mozambique, Malawi, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Tanzania, Kenya and Uganda.
No. Eritrea is not a target country for development assistance under Australiaâs Development Co-operation with Africa Framework for 2003-2007.

quote.para: While the questions specifically ask for the statistics in calendar years, historically the Office of the Privacy Commissioner has reported on these figures in financial years.Â Although a change to the Officeâs reporting software makes it possible to report in calendar years from 2002 onwards, for the sake of consistency, the Office has provided answers to all questions based on financial years.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

quote.para: How many times did the Attorney-General seek rulings from the Office of the Privacy Commissioner in (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, (e) 2004, and (f) 2005, and what did each ruling deal with.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: The Privacy Commissioner does not have the function of issuing rulings, therefore the answer to the honourable memberâs question is nil for each year.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: How many complaints relating to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) did the Privacy Commissioner receive in (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, (e) 2004, and (f) 2005.
Which issue received the (a) highest and (b) lowest number of complaints directed towards DFAT in (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, (e) 2004, and (f) 2005.
How many complaints did the Privacy Commissioner receive in relation to mandatory detention or from asylum-seekers in mandatory detention.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The number of complaints received by the Privacy Commissioner relating to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) were:
The issues raised in complaints against DFAT are as follows:

entry.para: An allegation of inadequate notice when collecting personal information under Information Privacy Principle (IPP) 2.
An allegation of improper use of personal information under IPP 10.
An allegation of inadequate security measures to protect personal information under IPP 4.
An allegation of improper disclosure of personal information under IPP 11 and inadequate security measures to protect personal information under IPP 4.
An allegation of unlawful/unfair collection of personal information under IPP 1.

item.para: How many complaints did the Privacy Commissioner receive in relation to mandatory detention or from asylum-seekers in mandatory detention.
The Office has received no complaints.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: How many policy advice documents did the Privacy Commissioner produce for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) in (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, (e) 2004, and (f) 2005.
What were the issues that the Privacy Commissioner gave advice to DFAT on in (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, (e) 2004, and (f) 2005.
Which issue received the (A) highest and (b) lowest number of policy advice documents for DFAT in (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, (e) 2004, and (f) 2005.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The number of policy advice documents produced by the Privacy Commissioner for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) were:
The issues the Privacy Commissioner gave advice to DFAT on are as follows:

entry.para: Letter provided advice regarding the accelerated release of records under the Archives Act 1983 (deceased persons in Timor in 74-76).
Letter provided advice regarding introduction of biometric identifier into Aus Passports, including notice to individuals, necessary uses of personal information.

Emails provided advice regarding the Bali tragedy and disclosures to the Australian Federal Police, other agencies such as Centrelink and the Child Support Agency, and other organisations including telecommunications providers and real estate agents.

Email providing advice regarding the Passports Act Revision Bill, including processes for validating passport application information and memoranda of understanding for overseas exchange of passport information.
Email providing advice regarding disclosure of passport information to the United States of America, including notification to individuals, data accuracy, and function creep.
Email providing advice regarding exchange of passport information with New Zealand, including complaint-handling mechanisms and data security.
Email providing advice on disclosure of Tsunami Missing Persons List.

item.para: The issue which received the highest and lowest number of policy advice documents for DFAT are as follows:

entry.para: Accelerated release of records under the Archives Act 1983 (1 policy advice document only).
New information handling arrangements in relation to Passports (3 policy advice documents all on this or related topics).
